The Ants Craft is a 7-year old Fair Trade community business that creates livelihoods for 4,000 Northeast Indian artisans. We return profits to the artisan community via higher wages and employing more people.  Most of our artisans are women, and the benefits of empowering women accrue to the whole family. 


We are raising $30,000 to equip a finishing unit in Bangalore to handle large export orders. LArger orders will allow us to provide sustainable employment for 15,000 artisans vs. 4,000. 
 

Here's our story.......
14 years ago, our parent organisation set up the the ant to work on health and education in Northeast
India. 



The 8 states of Northeast India - Assam, Arunachal Pradesh, Nagaland, Meghalaya,
Tripura, Sikkim, Mizoram, and Manipur - are beautiful and culturally diverse,
but economically impoverished. 







In these predominantly rural
communities, many families own neither land nor livestock. Men are forced to
work as day laborers and women as housemaids. There is little money for
education or healthcare. Any unforeseen expense, like a family member's illness, drives the
family into debt.




Determined to break this dependence, in 2002 Smitha Murthy, a textile designer and co-founder of The Ants Craft, started working with tribal
Bodo women to use their traditional weaving skills. Smitha focused on creating  designs for the urban market, introducing new yarns, colors, and designs.







Realizing that the women needed decision making power and control over their working conditions, we set up Aagor, a weavers' collective managed entirely by women. 

Initially we marketed the garments at exhibitions. Seeing that the weavers needed direct market access, in 2007 we opened the Ants Store in Bangalore, India.  And in 2013, we began selling online at The Ants Store.







We have been successful beyond our wildest dreams!  Beginning with a small group of Bodo women weavers of Assam, today we work with 4000 artisans all over the Northeast. 
We design, produce and sell garments, jewellery, baskets, pottery, food and toiletries. All our products are Fair Trade, and our artisans are paid fair wages; no child labor is used. 




     
 








But we stand at a crossroads today. Our store and online business are both doing well, but to truly grow and benefit more artisans, we have moved from a Trust to a for-profit enterprise with the same social cause. 


To grow, we need to efficiently handle the large export orders we are already receiving from Europe and the US. Currently we receive products from the Northeast and outsource their finishing, labelling and packing in Bangalore.  We can be far more efficient if we set up a finishing unit to handle these tasks ourselves. This will cost $30,000. 








By handling bigger orders, we can employ more artisans and we expect to benefit as many as 15,000 artisans by 2019, a 300% growth in beneficiaries! We can also employ up to 20 underprivileged people in Bangalore and ensure that our entire supply chain is Fair Trade. 



Every artisan we work with has a family. The extra income pays for better food, education and health care. It helps families pay off debts and become proud owners of land and livestock.


Help us make this happen! We ask you to support our dream of sustainable livelihoods that also protect beautiful traditional crafts.





What We Need & What You Get


We need $30,000 to set up our finishing unit in Bangalore, India. Take a look at our pie chart to see what we plan to spend it on.  We need 50% for raw materials and wages for the 20 underprivileged people we will employ in Bangalore; this is the only way we can ensure that we buy enough materials to handle large orders and pay the artisans and our workers on time.  







The machinery we plan to install includes professional sewing machines and pressing units. The office equipment comprises of laptops, high resolution printers and scanners for a Design Studio, plus studio tables and chairs for drafting/designing.  And the budget for samples includes trial runs to perfect production.


Any amount you choose to support our campaign is greatly appreciated. Funding starts at $1 and goes all the way to $1,000. 

 


Even if we raise less than $30,000, we will still begin our finishing unit on a smaller scale. We will put in fewer tailoring and pressing machines and hire fewer people, and will outsource the rest of the finishing until we raise the remaining money.

We have beautiful items available at every level of support. Jewelry boxes, silk stoles, Naga shawls....Take a look at snapshots below and the perk descriptions to see what we offer!


Your Perks




For $25 you receive a beautiful handbound notebook made from valuable reclaimed fabrics.




For $50 you receive a bead jewellery box beautifully decorated with colourful beads, cowrie shells, and semi-precious stones.


For $100 you receive a pair of Naga cushion covers.



For $250 you receive a beautiful rich blue silk scarf. Hand spun and hand woven by Bodo women in Assam.





For $500 you receive a beautiful and warm Pashmina scarf from Kashmir.



For $1000 you receive a traditional hand woven Naga shawl that takes an artisan a month to weave on a loin loom.


 
 
 
 
The Impact

Your support will allow us to reach 15,000 artisans in all 8 Northeast States by 2019, from the 4,000 we reach today! 

The supplementary income an artisan family can earn is an average of INR 1750 ($30 USD) per month, a 50% increase from their base income of INR 3500 ($60 USD) per month.  
Though these numbers may appear modest, in rural India this pays for significantly better food, education and health care. It 
helps families pay off debts and become proud owners of land and 
livestock.
Our work also has other social impacts: 




Risks & Challenges
The greatest risk we have is that our pipeline of wholesale orders will dry up. Today almost all our orders come from Europe and USA, but we have already begun to work with the Asian and Australian markets to mitigate this risk. We are confident that the finishing unit will help us produce high quality finished products, quick turnarounds on samples, and in fact help us gain business. 
In case we do end up with excess capacity in our unit, we plan to run the center as a community center where other non-profits and commercial enterprises in Bangalore can benefit from the finishing services. 
We have the confidence that we can execute this and use your money effectively.  After all, we have been doing this since 2000.....working with artisans, building a store, selling online.....now you can help us get to the next level! 


Other Ways You Can Help
 There are many ways to support us! Even if you can't contribute right now, we would be delighted if you can spread the word about our campaign to your friends, co-workers, and family.  Spread the word via Facebook, Twitter and other 
social media networks to let the world know about us!

story:
contribute, endorse and share... it's simple. 

our goal is 80% corporate pledges and 20% public contributions. Make a contribution today.

TUESDAY, APRIL 18, 2011  HelpJapanco passes $50,000 mark in private pledges and public contributions. ‎

TUESDAY, MARCH 22, 2011  $25,000 ‎secured in pledges and contributions in first 2 weeks!

SUNDAY, MARCH 20, 2011 Mr. Edward Miller Joins HelpJapan.co as it's CEO

PCNStrategies pledges $10,000. "Michael, Your effort in Japan is greatly needed! And you are the perfect person for the job at hand. It is my great please to pledge $10,000 to HelpJapan.co and encourage others to follow my lead. You have a clear and concise action plan. Good luck."  Mike Rosinbum CEO, PCNStrategies.com

"Michael J. Trout, a former ELT Teacher, passionate help help Japan recover. He has lives in Fukui with his wife and kids for the last 6 years near coastal communities similar to the ones that were wipe dout. He needs your support. He wants to provide direct help to coastal communities devastated by the 11-3-11 Tsunami. His solution is to make sure every shelter in Japan has clean water they can bath, cook or drink. He has partnered leading providers to bring services and solutions to help survivors.  Please help Michael Help Japan by making an non-tax deductible contribution-- thank you." David

 

We are a Social Venture Foundup® of Foundups Corp. a Delaware C-Corp headquartered in Washington, DC with representative offices in Fukui, Japan. We are not a nonprofit but a SOCIAL VENTURE to aid in Japan's recovery.   

One Minute Pitch - for those that want it fast!  

 

Please watch this Presentation

We want to open the doors to Japan to 4000+ Federal Contractor companies to participate in the recovery effort in Japan and re-invest all profits into helping the victims of the smaller communities recover. By doing this we can scale up extremely quickly and provide a sustainable, long-term solution for Japan and those that were impacted and will be impacted in the future! 

 

The Federal contractor network of companies have participated in providing every imaginable solution. They were involved in Katrina, Miami, Iraq and Afghanistan, 3mile Island nuclear disaster. They are capable of significantly aiding and helping Japan recover and in the process we can help America too!

story:
A FB comment that Anna made to me:  "Nate, I do love NOLA, but sometimes she can be a total bitch, and I just need a breather. But she has taken all my money and my ability to leave, so I'm a bit frustrated with her right now. she's been known to do that, invite people in, then leave them impoverished and trapped. haha. but yeah, basically, i love new orleans, it is my new home, but i need to be around my family right now (by which i mean my southern illinois family - the only REAL family i have) and i just can't seem to make it happen. and it's breaking my heart a little. or a lot."

I thought about this, and thought that I wanted to do something to help her out.  I mean, this isn't like me wanting to raise $8,000 to move to California.  She wants to come back and visit Carbondale!  Even after fundraising fees, $465 would be enough for a train ticket and food/expenses for at least two weeks!  $465 would go a long way!  So please, let us help Anna get that rejuvenation she needs through a visit to her Southern Illinois family!

Please feel free to share this with anyone who might be interested, as I have recently cleaned up my friends list and only have 20 mutual friends with Anna now.

story:
Our Story

Hello! My name is Kirill Yanishevsky.  As a Buddhist practitioner I've entered culinary school with an expectation that upon graduation I would start my own catering business that would provide for the community and the people. Since I've graduated I started a family and got a student loan, so that's why I did not have enough funds to start a catering company.  

The Impact

Food has a global impact on the people and the environment. My approach is holistic. I would use as much of local and seasonal products as possible, engage in recycling, composting, respect and provide people with love and warmth.  


What We Need & What You Get

My total fundraising goal is to raise $5,000.These funds will help me to acquire some essential catering equipment that would get me started towards accomplishing my dream. 


Other Ways You Can Help

If you are in the Chicago area you can spread the word about Picnic Catering.

story:
What's a Wesley Club?

  • The Wesley Club@UW is located in the University District in Seattle, where every day we share this neighborhood with people of many different backgrounds.
  • The Wesley Club is one of the very few progressive, LGBTQ affirming Christian campus ministries at the University of Washington.  We strive to promote openness and acceptance between all of our neighbors in the University District, though sometimes it's difficult to discern exactly how to do that.
  • By taking a group of students to serve at Glide UMC in San Francisco, we hope not only to serve within an established community support facility, but to discover how different kinds of outreach can engage diverse communities, and bring that knowledge back to the University District.

Why San Francisco?

Glide Memorial UMC, located in the heart of San Francisco, identifies as "a radically inclusive, just and loving community mobilized to alleviate suffering and break the cycles of poverty and marginalization." They've been serving daily free meals since 1969, and serve an average of 2,560 meals a day, offering breakfast, lunch and dinner to community members. With 45 years of experience serving their community, who could be a better model for what is possible in our community?

In addition to serving meals in Glide's daily free meal program and getting to know their specific community through service, we'll be learning about San Francisco's neighborhoods, demographics, and poverty. No two communities are exactly alike, and it's unrealistic to assume that we could bring back cookie cutter replicas of what we experience and learn at Glide, but with the combination of new knowledge of the unique community and equally unique service model, we hope to understand more about how to cater to the University District's specific needs.

We'll also focus on growing closer in community and spirituality. Many of us are exposed to a very homogenous worship experience. While in San Francisco, we'll be exploring a variety of different church services and worship styles. We'll attend services at Glide Memorial UMC and All Saint's Company, as well as worshiping together as a group each day. Each student will have a chance to share a devotion, challenging the group to more deeply process what they've seen, heard, experienced.

We Need Your Help!

The Wesley Club@UW is sending eight students, who will then join groups from Wesley Clubs at Western Washington University and Central Washington University. On March 20th, we'll load everyone up to drive down to San Francisco, spend six days serving, exploring, and growing, before again, loading up and heading back to Seattle. Your donations will help offset travel, lodging and food costs of $3,700 for the entire group. Each student is covering a portion of the trip expense out of pocket, but meeting our goal of $3,700 will ensure that all students are able to participate and afford the trip.

Risks & Challenges

We recognize that trips like these are very much give-and-take experiences. It's easy to focus on the immediate need we'll be fulfilling at Glide, and while this is important, we place emphasis on the relationships formed, the new perspectives gained, and the knowledge attained that we will bring back in order to continue serving in our own community.

Other Ways You Can Help

We can use all the help we can get! Here are ways in which you can help us reach our goal:

  • Donate to our campaign!
  • Share this website with friends and family - Get the word out!
  • Send us some good juju and prayers of safe travels and transformative experiences as we embark on this adventure!

Thank you, all, for your support!

story:
As I was leaving school today, I was fidgeting with my radio, trying to get it to work. I looked down for a few seconds too long and when I looked up traffic was stopping. I hit my brakes but my tires just skid along the pavement, I felt like it didn't slow down at all. Everyone was ok, no injuries, but my car was totaled in the end. I was able to drive it close by to my boyfriends house, but the radiator is busted and it won't go far without starting to smoke. I am in need of some funding to either replace or repair my car. I live in Auburn and work in downtown sac, as well as go to school in Rancho Cordova, so a car is a necessity as I commute a lot.

Any help would be appreciated, even if it's just $1-5, and if you can't help, please SHARE to get my page spread around.

I only have one month left in school before I graduate, I would hate to have to drop out because of this stupid mistake I made!

I am a single mom, trying to balance school, work and raising my 6 yr old son. Every day is a struggle and this just makes it so much harder on me. I don't have much family to help me, I don't have parents who can bail me out. I have no choice but to put my fate in the hands of the masses and hope and pray that I can raise enough to get me on the road again.

Thank you everyone for taking the time to read this, big thanks to those who share and huge thank you's to anyone who donates.

story:
Support the Youth

"I have a dream one day, to have a unified and structured community.  Have a voice in our society and support the youth with their projects."  -Deah Barakat

This fund is in honor of Deah Barakat, Yusor Abu-Salha and Razan Abu-Salha.  Our goal is to nurture, encourage, and empower local Muslim youth to achieve their goals now and to lead us in the future.  

The Healers of Tomorrow Youth Grants fund will be used specifically to support youth-led projects in Seattle and will not go towards any of MHP's other activities.

What You Get

We value transparency and hope to keep you involved as a community shareholder, and as such, every donor will be kept involved with the program activities. We will send out an email report with each activity so you can see exactly how your money was spent. 

You will also be invited to participate in activities periodically, so you have the opportunity to get to know the youth. We value your support. You are our greatest asset. 

Other Ways You Can Help: Be A Mentor

We are looking for mentors who can volunteer their time and love to empower our youth.  We have various mentorship opportunities, including one on one mentorship, speaking opportunities, and assistance in developing experiences such as shadowing or field trips.  Please email us (mhpgps@uw.edu) if you are ready to partner with our wonderful youth!

story:
Our Story

Great conversation holds the power to broaden perspectives, open minds and shape the direction of future leaders. The solutions to our most pressing issues--both worldly and personal--often stem from collaboration between trusted friends. As students at the University of Southern California taking a class called the Art and Adventure of Leadership, we enjoy the rare opportunity to talk with other students from all different aspects of campus life, whom we never would have met otherwise, about life, leadership, and our own burning questions. However, we realize that these insightful conversations don't just happen in every day social situations; they require a spark. 


Because we wanted to incite the same level of valuable conversation among our peers outside the class, and truly harness the potential of our generation as problem-solvers and innovators, we created the Spark Collective Supper Club: gatherings in the vein of the Salons of the Enlightenment Europe, which convene curious and passionate friends and strangers over a casual meal for an evening of thought-provoking dialogue. The suppers we have held so far have been tremendously successful. Attendees have departed with new friends, new ideas and a strong desire to host Spark Collective suppers of their own.


The suppers themselves are self-sustaining (guests contribute money via PayPal to cover the cost of the meals), but the Spark Collective Supper Club depends on a complex website for functionality. As the Spark Collective has grown, we have identified the need to create a website that can manage our unique invite mechanism that ensures fresh faces at every supper, handle multiple suppers at once, and organize our ever-expanding database of supper club attendees.

The Impact

The Spark Collective Supper Club touches and changes students' lives. Engineers meet gender studies majors and get to talk about family and growing up in a way they never before experienced. Sorority girls meet ROTC guys and learn to think about war and globalization in a way they never before considered. Futures and pasts unfold on the table as the food disappears. Guests leave with their bodies nourished from a home-cooked meal and their souls enriched from caring and challenging discourse. We believe that today's fast times and rapidly paced technological diversions distract our generation's attention from the issues that matter most. The Spark Collective Supper Club creates an intimate environment where students can let go of the outside world in order to truly see it. 

What We Need & What You Get

Help us foster the next generation of leaders. Help us cultivate the inquisitive, contemplative, creative minds that will usher in the next era. We need to build our website in order to give real life and longevity to the Spark Collective Supper Club. Without a solid virtual structure, the Spark Collective Supper Club will falter and perish--especially once we, the founding members, graduate in May. One simple online hub will keep Spark Collective Supper Club members connected, hosting and conversing. We need to raise about $3,000 to hire a designer and a coder to construct an aesthetically attractive and technically adequate site. With the money we raise, we also plan to expand to other schools, uniting students from even more diverse backgrounds to engage in even deeper conversation. 


As an official student organization at USC, we have access to a few hundred dollars in start-up money from the university. We are also pursuing other methods of online fundraising and entering several innovation competitions, so from IndieGoGo, we hope to raise $1,200. For donating, you'll get any of the wonderful Spark Collective gear listed on the right, from t-shirts to pint glasses to aprons.

Other Ways You Can Help

Spread the word! Tell people about our idea and post our link to your Facebook and Twitter. Encourage your friends to donate. One day soon we could bring the Spark Collective Supper Club to a campus near you. It's time to bring real conversation and collaboration to the table.

As the Spark Collective has grown, we have identified the need to create a website that can manage our unique invite mechanism that ensures fresh faces at every supper, handle multiple suppers at once, and organize our ever-expanding database of supper club attendees. 


The Impact
The Spark Collective Supper Club touches and changes students' lives. Engineers meet gender studies majors and get to talk about family and growing up in a way they never before experienced. Sorority girls meet ROTC guys and learn to think about war and globalization in a way they never before considered. Futures and pasts unfold on the table as the food disappears. Guests leave with their bodies nourished from a home-cooked meal and their souls enriched from caring and challenging discourse. We believe that today's fast times and rapidly paced technological diversions distract our generation's attention from the issues that matter most. The Spark Collective Supper Club creates an intimate environment where students can let go of the outside world in order to truly see it.  

What We Need & What You Get
Help us foster the next generation of leaders. Help us cultivate the inquisitive, contemplative, creative minds that will usher in the next era. We need to build our website in order to give real life and longevity to the Spark Collective Supper Club. Without a solid virtual structure, the Spark Collective Supper Club will falter and perish--especially once we, the founding members, graduate in May. One simple online hub will keep Spark Collective Supper Club members connected, hosting and conversing. We need to raise about $3,000 to hire a designer and a coder to construct an aesthetically attractive and technically adequate site. With the money we raise, we also plan to expand to other schools, uniting students from even more diverse backgrounds to engage in even deeper conversation. 

As an official student organization at USC, we have access to a few hundred dollars in start-up money from the university. We are also pursuing other methods of online fundraising and entering several innovation competitions, so from IndieGoGo, we hope to raise $1,200. For donating, you'll get any of the wonderful Spark Collective gear listed on the right, from t-shirts to pint glasses to aprons.

Other Ways You Can Help
Spread the word! Tell people about our idea and post our link to your Facebook and Twitter. Encourage your friends to donate. One day soon we could bring the Spark Collective Supper Club to a campus near you. It's time to bring real conversation and collaboration to the table.

story:
Help send us to Uganda to establish a women's empowerment and community center for the Mubende district's community social, economic and environmental development.



This project's purpose is to empower women and alleviate poverty within the

Mubende District through the establishment of a community center that will:

1. Provide workshops in the following areas:

a. Women's empowerment

b. Environmentally sustainable and higher yielding agricultural methods

c. Handicraft training and marketing

d. Family health and planning

2. Serve as a communal crop storage facility.

3. Establish a transportation system with the purchase of a truck for the center.


In order to see our vision through to completion, we are seeking funding to visit our target community in January to conclude our research, establish personal relationships within the region and have the most accurate information that will allow us to successfully move forward in this project's development in early 2012.


Our Story

We are part of a group of Harvard graduate students who have spent the semester
researching and planning a sustainable development project for the residents of
Kyakatebe, Uganda in the Mubende District.

Lene is a biology researcher at Harvard University and a student of sustainable
development. Having grown up in Norway with so much abundance, she has always felt
very fortunate and desired to share with others and help the less fortunate in any way
she can. When she joined the Art of Living Foundation in 2006, she knew her life path would include service projects around the world. With this project in Uganda
she hopes that with Kaley, in collaboration with the Art of Living Foundation, she can
make a difference for the women in Mubende and help them to help themselves out of
poverty.


A recent 19-year-old graduate of Boston University, Kaley is currently pursuing her
Master's at Harvard and hopes to complete her thesis on gender and development
work. She has traveled extensively in over 30 countries and, like Lene, wishes to help
women around the world realize their self-worth and maximize their potential, as she
has felt so lucky to experience so much herself in the United States.


This proposal is the culmination of a sustainable development class project that seeks to target the three key areas of sustainable development: economic, social and environmental benefits. Our immediate goal is to travel to Uganda to more effectively implement our project in a way that benefits the entire community for years to come.


The Impact

Our proposed Community Center will be a gift that will sustainably give to the Mubende
district, eventually leading to self-sustainability and a potential rise out of poverty.
We will construct a Community and Women's Empowerment Center that aims to
positively resonate through our target district, Kyakatebe, on numerous levels:
empowering women toward greater skills leading to financial and political autonomy,
encouraging communal development, increasing crop longevity and yieldby delivering
environmentally friendly methods, increasing profits by granting villagers greater
autonomy, and improving the livelihoods of all that are involved.

This project is designed to respond to Kyakatebe's actual needs and include the
participation of the entire community for its implementation, monitoring and continuation.
In collaboration with the Art of Living Foundation (AOLF), an Empowerment Workshop
will be organized for the women participating in the project. The local AOLF group will
follow up and give support to the project on a regular basis to ensure the long-term
success and development of the project.

With a well-established connection to a church community in the capital city of Kampala
through Pastor Israel Ssekamatte, we have access to detailed information about the
target community and resources available in the area. This will further secure proper
monitoring of the project and a successful exit strategy following our contributions.

What We Need

Our budget for the whole project is estimated at $28,000 which includes the purchase
of the land ($5,263), building construction ($5,500), truck to deliver goods to market
($7,500 + maintainance), instructors ($3,000), center furnishings
($1,000), associated fees ($300), and Miscellaneous costs. We intend on
submitting our formal proposal for grant funding, but wish to get this program off the
ground independently as early as possible.

With the $3,400 we are requesting here,
Lene and Kaley will both be able to fly to Uganda, personally meet the local facilitators,
assess the land, evaluate the proposed building plan and project implementation as a
whole. Furthermore, we will meet with the women of Kyakatebe to give them information
as to how our project will positively resonate with them and effectively address their
needs.

If you have any questions or seek any further details of our project, please do not
hesitate to contact us. Thank you!

Thank you!

story:
Our Story

We are working to help Peter Kiula, a 35 year old gentleman who is losing most of his teeth to decay at such a young age.  Peter arrived in New York three years ago from Tanzania to live his American dream.  Peter is currently a cook at the famous New York City deli named Kalustyans on 28th and Lexington.

 

Our goal is to raise $5,000 for a full mouth dental reconstruction for Peter.  Until we decided to help Peter, he had never been to a dentist in his life, and as a result his teeth had reached a state where if something was not done to stop the decay and repair the teeth, he would lose all his teeth.

 

Trained as a journalist in Tanzania, Peter is also an excellent cook, and his skills provided him the opportunity to start work as a cook at the famous New York Mediterranean deli named Kalustyans. As visible in the photo, Peter has missing teeth, and the remaining teeth are decayed and stained. Peter is always smiling in life, even with his condition.  He is always helpful, warm, and welcoming to all his customers at Kalustyans, and we want to help him have the brilliant smile that he deserves. 

 

In November 2010, we began the journey to help Peter get his smile back.  Peter has gone through two stages of treatment: Stage 1 prepped his mouth to a clean state, including root canals, fillings, and extractions.  Stage 2, completed right before Christmas, helped Peter get prepared for his new teeth by providing him temporary veneers.  Now Stage 3 is remaining, where we hope to get Peter his permanent new teeth to complete his brilliant smile.  We are raising money to cover the costs of all three stages of Peter's treatment.  Working in conjuction with the highly expert team of Dr. Michael Iott and Dr. Shireen Malik, Peter is in exraordinarily good hands for his treatment.  The website for Dr. Iott is http://www.smiletonight.com/, where you can see examples of his work.  


The Impact

We would like your help to make Peter’s dream to smile, a reality. Every human being deserves to have teeth and the ability to chew, eat, and smile. Peter loves to share his exuberant and optimistic spirit by smiling at others...and now Peter deserves to have a completely beautiful smile. 

Your help can go a long way to help him achieve this dream. Your donation can help change the smile above to a beaming beautiful smile. This is a perfect opportunity for you to be a part of a young man's dream come true in the heart of New York City. 

If Peter doesn't get his teeth fixed, he will continue lose most of the teeth to decay, be unable to eat solid foods, and most of all, be unable to share his positive outlook on life via the basic human right to smile.  Peter is too young at the age of 35 to have to suffer such a fate. His being in New York makes it easy for all of us to help him. 

What We Need & What You Get

We need to raise $5,000 to help cover the costs of Peter's treatment.  The actual cost of such a full-mouth dental reconstruction would cost $70,000 in New York City, but the dental team (Dr. Iott and Dr. Malik) have been generous in donating their time, resources, and expertise in treating Peter.  However, the cost for materials and lab fees to create Peter’s new teeth and veneers has to be covered, and we need $5,000 in funding for this. We encourage you to donate whatever amount you feel happy giving.  Here are some suggestions:

 

$300 - donation will get you a signed copy of Peter's before and after photo of his teeth and new smile! 

 

$500 - donation will get you the above signed photo, as well as two free lunches at Kalustyans deli (valid for one year), made by Peter the cook!

 

$1000 - donation will get you all of the above, plus a private cooking lesson for two with Peter, so you can learn the secrets behind his amazing dishes!


 

Other Ways You Can Help

You can also help by letting your friends and contacts know about this opportunity to help grant the opportunity for someone to smile in New York. 

 

To make it easy, you can:

1. Add the link to this fundraising page to your Facebook status.

2. Email your friends and colleagues about this great opportunity.

 

We all know New York can only be helped if one more person can beam a smile. No one deserves to lose their teeth, especially at the young age of 35.  Peter needs your help so he can continue to shine his warmth as part of the fabric of New York City and continue to work on his American dream.

story:
5 DAYS LEFT TO CHOOSE A PLAN

Friday is the final day for free Ning Networks

On 2/14/2008, a new social network popped up on the Internet. Ours:

http://p2pfoundation.ning.com

This network has grown up a bit since we started the ball rolling. We’ve 689 members who have collectively helped add 39 photos, 25 videos, and 101 spirited discussions. Well done!

We’d like to see this continue

Ning contacted us today to remind us that we still have time to choose a new Ning plan. But, time is running out. If we do not choose a new plan by this Friday, August 20, 2010, the community we built will be lost*

(*well, actually, we’ve run the Ning Archiver tool and will run it again at the last minute to make sure we’ve captured the latest member data and content on the Ning, so all will not be lost, but there will be some down time whilst a new home is built)

story:
Our Story

We need you to help us reach our goal of $7,000 in UNDER 20 DAYS! The $7,000 that is raised will be used for the interior renovation of the new coffee shop.
 
The Roast is a student-led initiative to open a community-themed coffee shop on College Hill across the street from the University of Northern Iowa. The idea started with a group of students looking for a cool and creative place to hang out. The closest coffee shop to campus is 2 miles away, while The Roast will be an alternative place to socialize, study, and snack on College Hill in Cedar Falls. Unlike any other coffee shop, ours is student run and will fill the void of a local meeting place for the Cedar Falls and UNI community.
 
With the combination of enthusiastic students, professional advice, and YOUR support, The Roast coffee shop will be established as the new social gathering place for the Cedar Valley in August 2012.
 

The Impact

The Roast will greatly impact the culture of College Hill, the community of Cedar Falls, and the lives of the students and faculty at the University of Northern Iowa.  Without the Roast, activities on College Hill are limited to bars, restaurants and tanning salons, and we want to provide an appealing alternative to that! Not only will the Roast provide the community of Cedar Falls with a great atmosphere to study and socialize in, but it will also be an art venue for student painters, photographers and musicians.  Whether you want to stop by for a quick coffee in between classes, or just need a good atmosphere to hang out, The Roast will make that possible. 
 

What We Need & What You Get

 
Our main priority is to open for business in August of 2012! To do this we need help from you, fellow students, faculty and community members to "Help the Hill" and bring The Roast to life. The money raised through this campaign will go towards the start up costs mainly including supplies, equipment, and furniture. Other start-up costs will be obtained through private investments and a loan. The more that is raised now, the more likely The Roast will be successful in the long-run.
 
We've come up with the coolest and most supportive benefits possible. We want to thank you for supporting The Roast, and we want everyone to know that you were part of this endeavor to help a community in need. We need a minimum of $7,000 to get started on the interior rennovations and construction. If we exceed our goal, we can make quicker progress and get the shop here even sooner! If we  all fall short of our goal, there will still be a coffee kiosk on College Hill with the goal of eventually opening the real coffee shop. 
 

Other Ways You Can Help

If you can't donate money, we can still use your help! We need all the help we can get in spreading the word, and making some noise about The Roast!  You can impact the success of this campaign by sharing it with your friends on Facebook, Twitter, Linked-in, old-fashioned word-of-mouth, and any other way possible.  
 
We also value your ideas and would love to hear your thoughts.  If you have an idea for the Roast or want to help in any way, let us know!
 
Email: info@theroastcf.com
 
For more info: www.TheRoastCF.com
 
THANK YOU!
From: The Roast team, Coffee Shop lovers, and most of all, Your Local Community

story:
A little bit about me . . .

                                          

I've been a freelance writer and blogger for three years, and in that time I've branched out into editing, social media marketing and promotional work for authors. I write on a (mostly) successful blog The Insomniacs Dream, and I was published in two anthologies; "Sunshine After the Storm" and "To Bliss and Back (Life Well Blogged)". 

                                                

Most recently, I’ve found myself helping self-published authors, bloggers, and website owners promote themselves and their products online via Social Media and other methods, including blog tours.  I discovered I had a knack for this, and that I really enjoyed doing it.  I began taking on a few promotional gigs from local authors in addition to my freelancing work.   Most recently, I wrapped up a blog tour for the bestselling author and concert promoter, Pat DiCesare. 

Thus began my journey out of the freelancing world and into a more business focused world, centered on this new passion of organizing blog tours and other promotional avenues for authors to get their books out there into the world.

I’ve enjoyed it so much that I’ve decided to make it my full time job and start a business.

                                            

Why Starry Knight Word Slayers?

As I began networking locally here in Pittsburgh at writing seminars and conferences, and getting my name out there by word of mouth over the Internet, I’ve definitely noticed a need for this type of service.  There are so many authors out there with great stories to tell, but they flounder about in a crowded sea of fellow authors, and sometimes, their words (and books) get lost.

While I’ve found the niche, and the need, for the business, I’ve also come to the conclusion that I need a more professional way of touting my wares.  In the three years that I have been a freelancer, I’ve found my work mainly through online hiring places for freelancers or by word of mouth.  The majority of my clientele was referred to me by previous or current clients.

I need more than word of mouth and recommendations.  To achieve this, I require a solid, professional online business.  I can attend all the writing seminars in the Tri-State area, but unfortunately without a website to guide people to, my business cards can get lost, and the opportunity for both the author to promote their book and for me to have another client is long gone. 

I’ve been selling my products from the trunk of my car, but it has come time for me to have a store front, if you’ll allow the metaphor.  With a professional website, a potential client would be able to view the packages and services I offer, blog tours and promotional events on Social Media I’ve done in the past, and testimonials all in one convenient place. No longer will I have to chase down references via email, save testimonials on my computer to share with potential clients, and go back and forth via email and Social Media to show them what I can do for them. 




I plan to launch a virtual company that offers all of my services to include the writing, editing, and social media I’ve always done and thus carry over current clients, but will also put a spotlight on my newest and most exciting branch of the business:  author and book promotions.   I intend to expand the promotional offerings to include a book review listing authors can place their books on, social media parties, cover and trailer reveals, and much more.

I have a solid team behind me of talented and dedicated bloggers who have worked with me on blog tours and social media promotions in the past and remain on my list of hosts for current and upcoming blog tours. 

Here's what just two of them have to say about working with me:

                                                      

"I've worked with Starr on a number of campaigns. She's always done the heavy lifting, told me exactly what was expected and smoothed any issues that popped up. I'd definitely recommend her to other writers and bloggers." - Tamara Woods, author of "The Shaping of an 'Angry' Black Woman."          

               

                                                     

Starr is terrific to work with! She is professional, personable, and organized. Starr walks you through every step of the process, communicating clearly and effectively what you need to do and when. She makes things very simple and does it with a smile. - Lisa A. Listwa, writer at "The Meaning of Me."


The services I will provide to independent and self-published authors will be offered at realistic and affordable prices.  I understand that authors who publish themselves don’t have the funds to throw at promotion for their books that they often wish they did.  With me by their side, they will have access to thousands of potential readers in a variety of ways at rates they can afford.

                               

Where you come in . . .

Of course, as with every start-up company, even the virtual kind, there are costs.  Being a writer and independently published author myself, I’m not necessarily making it rain.  I’m a single Mom with bills to pay, including child support when the boys are with their Dad.  I’ve emptied out my pockets, even turned them inside out, and the funds are just not there to get Starry Knight Word Slayers off the ground and launched into something wonderful. 

                                            

This is where you come in.  With YOUR help, I can launch the business.  Funds raised in this campaign will go towards the purchase of advertising and promotional items I need, help me make it to some of the top writing seminars in Pittsburgh to network with authors, and pay for the website, the graphic designs, and all of the marketing costs I will incur over the next few months.

                                          

Below, you will see a chart of predicted costs to get my dream company up and off the ground, as well as the costs to maintain it in the first few months.  I have done extensive research, and in some cases gotten an exact estimate.  These figures are as close to the real cost that I could find. 

Predicted Costs

Domain and Hosting for 1st year

   15.00

Graphic Design

  100.00

Web Design

  635.00

Advertising, Marketing, Seminar Costs

  408.00

Promotional Items 

(Business Cards, Pens, Bookmarks, etc)

  490.00

Total :

1648.00


If I raise enough funds to hit my goal and donations continue to filter in, I plan to use the extra money for additional items for the business.  Any money raised will be put right back into Starry Knight Word Slayers; with additional funds I will attend more seminars, put out more ads and do more online marketing, buy additional promotional items, and even be able to put more money into the design and graphics for the website.

Are there perks?  You bet there are!

If you’re one of the wonderful people that contribute to this campaign, you will get perks!  You can see all of the perks on the side bar to the right, at the different levels of donation.

The perks for the $40 and over donations offer a choice:  If you’re an author and you could use a free blog tour in the near future I encourage you to choose that as your perk.  However, if you’re not an author, or do not have a need for a blog tour, I have offered ad space on the website.  You do not have to be a business to run an ad; you can advertise your blog, your social media, anything you’d like- even if it’s just your name!

Just another fine example of why I need some professionals on the scene. This is my current "place holder" graphic for my blog tour packages. 

The" Slayers Wall of Fame" will be a dedicated page on my website showcasing all of the contributors from the campaign that receive that perk.

Let’s Do This

Help me launch Starry Knight Word Slayers and let’s get more books out there into the world and more people reading!
story_txt:
A little bit about me . . .                                          I've been a freelance writer and blogger for three years, and in that time I've branched out into editing, social media marketing and promotional work for authors. I write on a (mostly) successful blog The Insomniacs Dream, and I was published in two anthologies; "Sunshine After the Storm" and "To Bliss and Back (Life Well Blogged)".                                                 Most recently, I’ve found myself helping self-published authors, bloggers, and website owners promote themselves and their products online via Social Media and other methods, including blog tours.  I discovered I had a knack for this, and that I really enjoyed doing it.  I began taking on a few promotional gigs from local authors in addition to my freelancing work.   Most recently, I wrapped up a blog tour for the bestselling author and concert promoter, Pat DiCesare. Thus began my journey out of the freelancing world and into a more business focused world, centered on this new passion of organizing blog tours and other promotional avenues for authors to get their books out there into the world.I’ve enjoyed it so much that I’ve decided to make it my full time job and start a business.                                            Why Starry Knight Word Slayers?
As I began networking locally here in Pittsburgh at writing seminars and
conferences, and getting my name out there by word of mouth over the Internet,
I’ve definitely noticed a need for this type of service.  There are so
many authors out there with great stories to tell, but they flounder about in a
crowded sea of fellow authors, and sometimes, their words (and books) get lost.While I’ve found the niche, and the need, for the business, I’ve also come to the conclusion that I need a more professional way of touting my wares.  In the three years that I have been a freelancer, I’ve found my work mainly through online hiring places for freelancers or by word of mouth.  The majority of my clientele was referred to me by previous or current clients.I need more than word of mouth and recommendations.  To achieve this, I require a solid, professional online business.  I can attend all the writing seminars in the Tri-State area, but unfortunately without a website to guide people to, my business cards can get lost, and the opportunity for both the author to promote their book and for me to have another client is long gone. I’ve been selling my products from the trunk of my car, but it has come time for me to have a store front, if you’ll allow the metaphor.  With a professional website, a potential client would be able to view the packages and services I offer, blog tours and promotional events on Social Media I’ve done in the past, and testimonials all in one convenient place. No longer will I have to chase down references via email, save testimonials on my computer to share with potential clients, and go back and forth via email and Social Media to show them what I can do for them. I plan to
launch a virtual company that offers all of my services to include the writing,
editing, and social media I’ve always done and thus carry over current clients,
but will also put a spotlight on my newest and most exciting branch of the
business:  author and book promotions.   I intend to expand the promotional offerings to include a book review listing authors can place their books on, social media parties, cover and trailer reveals, and much more.
I have a solid
team behind me of talented and dedicated bloggers who have worked with me on blog tours and social media promotions in the past and remain on my list of hosts for current and upcoming blog tours. Here's what just two of them have to say about working with me:                                                      "I've worked with Starr on a number of campaigns. She's always done the heavy lifting, told me exactly what was expected and smoothed any issues that popped up. I'd definitely recommend her to other writers and bloggers." - Tamara Woods, author of "The Shaping of an 'Angry' Black Woman."                         

                                                     Starr is terrific to work with! She is professional, personable, and organized. Starr walks you through every step of the process, communicating clearly and effectively what you need to do and when. She makes things very simple and does it with a smile. - Lisa A. Listwa, writer at "The Meaning of Me."The services I will provide to independent and self-published authors will be offered at realistic and affordable prices.  I understand that authors who publish themselves don’t have the funds to throw at promotion for their books that they often wish they did.  With me by their side, they will have access to thousands of potential readers in a variety of ways at rates they can afford.

with every start-up company, even the virtual kind, there are costs.

rain.  I’m a single Mom with bills to pay, including child support when
the boys are with their Dad.  I’ve emptied out my pockets, even turned

story:
Welcome to our Indiegogo page!

Global Village Fruits is a for-profit social enterprise building international supply chains for undiscovered, underutilized superfruits.

We first discovered jackfruit when our founder, Annie, was working in southern India to adapt and implement a maternal and child healthcare program she, her brother, and a classmate co-founded.

Annie, her brother Alex, and staff members pose for a photo at Dindavara primary health center in rural southern India
 

It was love at first taste. 

Annie + Jackfruit = <3

Annie had never tasted anything as delicious as the jackfruit. Unable to understand why she had never tasted this wonderfruit before, she delved into research and began attending jackfruit festivals, conversing with jackfruit experts, and visiting jackfruit farms and processing facilities.

Discovering that most of India's jackfruit is simply wasted for various gaps in the supply chains, Annie decided to launch Global Village Fruits to remedy multiple problems. Preventing jackfruit wastage would mean boosting the income of farmers and processors, empowering women with paid employment, and making this superfruit accessible in her homeland.

We did a Kickstarter campaign in February 2012. Those funds lifted us up and got us going! We set up an initial website and got barcoding, insurance, packaging, product, and shipping for a sample load of jackfruit products.

A GVF jackfruit taste-testing booth at a local specialty food store

Since then, Annie has traveled to India two more times (with funding support from school) to really understand the issues.

Annie discusses jackfruit harvesting and processing with a jackfruit expert at the University of Agricultural Sciences, Bangalore.

 

Annie discusses supply chain challenges with jackfruit farmers and processors.
 
Annie markets jackfruit products with friends, farmers, and processors at a Bangalore jackfruit festival.
 
Annie tries to prepare tender jackfruit for cooking.
 
Annie removes jackfruit bulbs from jackfruit rind in a jackfruit processing training program.
 
Annie assists (mostly as taste-tester) in a day-long jackfruit cooking celebration.
 

Yep, Annie and the team are just as excited as ever (more excited is not possible) to bring jackfruit to your doorstep.

Building a Brand

We aim to be the enterprise to introduce jackfruit, in all its wonder, to the US, and we're building a brand that communicates our vibrant spirit and innovation as well as our commitment to positive social and environmental impact. Our new, fully printed stand-up pouches are at the press. We're re-doing our website.

Our new logo!
 

Why Indiegogo?

Practically speaking, we've got a cash-flow problem. We expect to profit from sales over time, but we've got to buy our product inventory first. We don't have that kind of cash in the bank (although we definitely haven't paid ourselves for anything just yet--saving money for product and impact).

Which brings me to my next point--we've got a ton to do! Global Village Fruits isn't only buying, importing, packaging, marketing, and selling product. We're also conducting processing training programs and working to establish processing facilities in which we can ensure that we maximize our positive social and environmental impacts. (And we also don't yet have the cash in the bank for all of this, although we have done 12 training programs, and we know what equipment we need and where to get it.)

Another reason? I, Annie, am now working full-time on Global Village Fruits!!! :D!! Yep, first time in my 22 years of existence in memory that I'm not in school. I've finally got the opportunity to invest all the time and energy I have into realizing our team's dreams for Global Village Fruits. We will be fundraising in a big way (think angel investors and impact investors) after product hits shelves in August--but we need some help to get there.

Last reason--we believe that jackfruit is the next BIG thing. This is the beginning of our major social media campaign to tell the world about this superfruit. Spread the word--join and help us build the GVF jackfruit fan club.

Rewards

We hope you're excited as we are to delight in the mango-pineapple-banana taste of jackfruit! Our premiere product is dried jackfruit, packed with potassium, magnesium, and fiber. (That's it on the right!)

Jackfruit (rind) meets dried jackfruit (bulbs).

But that's not all! We've also got jackfruit lassi, sweet jackfruit bars (you've got to pause for dessert sometimes), crispy jackfruit chips (a snacking favorite among our teammates in India), GVF T-shirts, GVF tote bags (100% organic!), a sample pack of yet-to-be-released exotic fruit products (o_O), an amazing India trip itinerary + travel tips, a Whole Foods dinner party in your honor, and the opportunity to adopt a jackfruit tree. (Read more on the column to your right!)

And then, for those of you who want to make an extremely tangible contribution to the development of this social enterprise, we've also got several [IMPACT] reward options. Your contribution would go directly toward the construction of a processing facility to support the livelihoods of farmers and processors, and we would send you photos of the equipment in action.

So, DON'T MISS OUT! 

One monkey makes a run for the jackfruit. Other monkey misses out.

But really, 

Thanks a ton for stopping by!

We really, really appreciate your support.

<3 Annie, Greta, Celia, Joe, and Marjorie

Would you like to contact us? Please email annie@globalvillagefruits.com

story:
Help us send youth on day-long retreats to deepen their YOGA practices and build COMMUNITY.

YOU can make an impact by supporting our youth leaders and their initiative to broaden their experience of yoga beyond our formal programs.  Watch the video and BE INSPIRED!

About Us

New Leaf Yoga Foundation started 6 years ago and is a charitable organization in Canada making yoga and life skills programs accessible to youth where it has been least available.

The Project

This year we launched an exciting new initiative in the northwest Toronto neighbourhood of Rexdale, called Free Up.

The program offers youth between the ages of 13 and 24 the opportunity to learn yoga and mindfulness practices in a familiar space within their own community through free drop-in classes where food is provided and transportation is subsidized for those who attend.

A team of amazing youth leaders has grown out of the Free Up classes, and they have initiated a fundraising campaign to support a series of day-long retreats and outings designed to take their yoga practices further and build an even stronger sense of community amongst Free Up participants.

The outings will involve intenstive yoga and meditation sessions, guest yoga teachers and trips to yoga studios around Toronto, introductory classes in other mindfulness-based modalities such as martial arts and theatre, as well as motivational speakers and mentors from their community.  Our aim is to provide youth with varied and fresh experiences of the practices they have already begun to nourish.

Please support our youth leaders and their blossoming Free Up community by checking out this awesome video 100% created by members of our Free Up Rexdale initiative and BE INSPIRED to give big and support their yoga journey!

 

What We Need

Your very-generously-donated dollars will go towards:

  • stipends for our guest  yoga teachers and session facilitators
  • honorariums for youth leaders
  • subsidizing expenses for youth to travel beyond the community where they live
  • healthy meals and snacks as part of the retreats

The amount we raise will determine the number of day retreats we can hold in the upcoming year and what they can include.  Eventually we'll be working up to raising funds for a weekend-long residential yoga retreat for our youth particiipants!

The Impact

At New Leaf we believe that yoga helps youth tap into their inner resources and create more peace in their lives. 

YOUR support will help us provide even more opportunities to the young people we work with AND will provide leadership and mentoring roles from some of our participants --- youth supporting their peers in their own community.

Other Ways You Can Help

Please consider sharing this campaign on your social media and help us get the word out!  We so appreciate anything you can do to help us meet our goal.

story:
Short Summary

I have been racing in go karts for about three years, but last year I advanced to the much more competitive Rotax Max Sprint Kart series.
 
In my first year, I have qualified to race in the Rotax Max Grand Nationals which this year will be held neart my hometown in Mooresville, NC.
 
Racing is very expensive and my parents and some sponsors have covered the cost of my monthly racing, but it is very expensive to race in Grand Nationals even without travel expenses for me.
 
Funds that I raise will go to:
 
  • Entry Fees (About $1,000)
  • Fuel (About $150)
  • Crew & Crew Travel Expenses (About 1,400)
  • Coaching (About $250)
  • Tires (About $750)

 

I have raised some of this from local sponsors, but still have a long way to go.


Anything you can do to help will be greatly appreciated!  No amount is too small!

 

Thank You!

 

Alex

story:
I seek donation to afford the Social Good Summit in New York City.

http://mashable.com/sgs/

This is a three day conference which will be a meeting of innovative voices and ideas  to bring together a global social good community through new technology and media.

Why?

Something has been happening to me lately.

Sensations in my gut have become more pronounced. 

My passions have begun to direct themselves toward a dynamic interaction with the world around me.

 Diving into this society by cultivating inspiration, creation and a pursuit of knowledge is how I have decided to live my life.

I wish to take a grassroots approach toward being a positive change in this world. Toward inspiring the young minds of this generation by empowering their imaginations and illuminating the potential of this existence. 

By pursuing a diversity of opportunities, I will actualize a foundation of strength to move forward from.

 I will equip myself to be not only a potent social activist but an emboldening educator. 

Make me electric, give me some change.

<3

story:
Help Joe Fournier because he risked it for you and stood up and said it’s not OK to take advantage of others.

Joe has stood up to a Non Profit organization that is supposed to help inventors where he was working as the Director, Corporate Membership Services at the United Inventors Association of America.

 Joe found that this organization wasn't screening its sponsored member companies that are (invention related service providers), as they posted on their website. This meant that less than ethical companies were free to take advantage of unknowing inventors. Along with this, Joe found that its Executive Director MARK T. REYLAND was copying an inventor’s product he was supposedly a friend of. Then the UIA President WARREN TUTTLE submitted both the inventor’s product and the copycat product by Mark Reyland to the same company where he is employed as a scout.  Through that company, Warren Tuttle got The Trapdoor Colander licensed. The UIA is supposed to be a non-profit that helps inventors, not copy their products and rip them off.

 The photo above is the copy of this product http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=NU93SPoDBJY  made by the Executive Director MARK T. REYLAND of the UIA.  He claims to have helped get the inventor’s product to market.  That is a lie, he had no part in it).

 Joe posted this and the information about the sponsored companies not being screened as promoted by the UIA to all 14.000 of its members in an attempt to warn the inventors of the unethical behavior of its Executive Director MARK T. REYLAND. YOU CAN READ IT HERE.

http://inventorswelcome.blogspot.com/2013/05/insider-blows-whistle-on-united.html

Joe's last pay check was withheld until he agreed not to post this information on LinkedIn inventors groups. The Executive Director MARK T. REYLAND demanded this of him.  Joe's own daughters earnings for scanning UIA receipts was withheld.  The $35 owed to her also wasn't going to be paid.

 Joe has undergone 2 surgeries to his spine so far and a fusion will be scheduled soon. With all this against him, he still did the right thing and blew the whistle on this Non-profit.  It’s a long story that you can read on these blogs:   http://inventorswelcome.blogspot.com/

                                    And

          http://uialiesreyland.blogspot.com/

 We are asking for help for Joe for helping us, inventor or not, it’s people like Joe that force changes and make a fair playing field for all. $25 will pay a co-pay visit to his doctor, $50 will help him feed his family, $100 will help pay the electric bill and car payment. This man cannot work, he is totally disabled and social Security disability takes months, if not years to be granted. His wife is the families sole support and she works endlessly and is working overtime to try and keep food on the table and pay the bills that are getting farther behind.

This is a request to do the right thing for a man that did the right thing., He took the risk and followed through while bed ridden and unselfishly put himself on the chopping block for all people that have been deceived and taken advantage of.

 And after this, the Executive Director MARK T. REYLAND posted this lie about Joe on the UIA website.  (Joe has never been convicted of a felony).  This shows just how truly unethical and unprofessional this Non-profit really is. It’s nothing less than DISGRACEFUL!   The supposed author of this letter, Greg Amundson said he didn't write it when he was asked on the phone about it.  It was made up by the Executive Director MARK T. REYLAND of the United Inventors Association. And the President WARREN TUTTLE allows this to happen.

 THIS WAS POSTED ON THE UIA WEBSITE TO DISCREDIT JOE FOURNIER.  IT’S 100% LIES.

 May 17, 2013

   From:  A fellow Inventor I got the emails this week like everybody else. But what I know is Joe Fournier is a convicted Felon who spent three years in prison for theft and computer hacking. I also know Mark Reyland took a chance on him when no one else would.

 I have worked with Mark Reyland and the Directors of the UIA for over 4 years now.  Mark has become a good friend of ours and his integrity, honesty and helpfulness is paramount.

 We started our the pursuit of our invention 4 years ago at the Inventors Congress Show in Redwood Falls, MN where we were first introduced to Mark Reyland. Mark was the kind of guy that was not there to provide false hope or tell you that you would make a bunch of money with your idea.  He was very direct and to the point.  Some of his comments stung a little and I remember being more than tweaked at what he told me I had to change to become successful with our product.  After that Show I realized he was right and I worked toward making some of these changes which have gotten us to where we are today.

 That was 4 years ago and today we find ourselves in a wonderful position with opportunities I could never of dreamed of with numerous national companies.

 But, we would not be where we are without the help of MarkReyland. Period!  Mark was always been there to help in his direct no BS style.  Many times he was quite critical but in hindsight he was almost always right.

When I read stories about Mark Reyland stealing inventor’s ideas or running the UIA for the benefit of the invention companies it couldn’t be further from the truth.  Mark has had many opportunities to send us in directions that would benefit him financially but he has never done so. Mark has always been very honest and open about inventor companies good and bad.  To this day, Mark has provided us with guidance and honesty that has benefited us without any financial gain for himself.

Mark Reyland is not the only one at the UIA that has provided help in our pursuit of becoming a successful company.  Warren Tuttle and the other directors have provided valuable assistance many times over without benefit to themselves.

I may never understand what caused the lashing out by a past employee of the UIA but I can honestly say that Mark Reylandand the Board of Directors at the UIA have always had our best interests first and foremost.

We owe a lot of our success to them and very much appreciate it.

 Greg Amundson

Www.cornerflex.com

 Posted by Mark Reyland at 9:45 AM
story_txt:
Help Joe Fournier because he risked it for you and stood up and said it’s not OK to take advantage of others.
Joe has stood up to a Non Profit organization that is supposed to help inventors where he was working as the Director, Corporate Membership Services at the United Inventors Association of America.
 Joe found that this organization wasn't screening its sponsored member companies that are (invention related service providers), as they posted on their website. This meant that less than ethical companies were free to take advantage of unknowing inventors. Along with this, Joe found that its Executive Director MARK T. REYLAND was copying an inventor’s product he was supposedly a friend of. Then the UIA President WARREN TUTTLE submitted both the inventor’s product and the copycat product by Mark Reyland to the same company where he is employed as a scout.  Through that company, Warren Tuttle got The Trapdoor Colander licensed. The UIA is supposed to be a non-profit that helps inventors, not copy their products and rip them off.

story:
This facility assists people in obtaining food, shelter, and work so as to co-exist in a civilized society. Our programs are designed to empower individuals who are motivated to become self-sufficient and better their lives for a brighter future. Programs and services are available to everyone regardless of faith, race, or gender. Our hope is for all of our clients to have the ability to reach his or her full potential.

We believe it is the right of every man, woman, and child to have access to affordable housing, a sufficient food supply and ability to work for a living.

We are a day and night shelter for men, and families. We have one wing exclusively reserved for military veterans. Family is this: man & woman, or man & woman with children. Also, no one is turned down that needs a meal.


At present we are at full capacity within our family wing, $5000 of the funds we need will go directly to outfitting another wing to provide for additional families. We have turned away, just this week alone, several families due to lack of space.

The remaining $2500 is for payment on a security bond we owe for from the first of this year to cover the cost of a power bill.

Any funds received will be applied to these issues, no matter the amount. To any and all who contribute- your effort to support will help continue the changing of lives and replace Hope in people who have felt hopeless long enough.

Those here who facilitate are all volunteers, no one is paid monies for there service. To see children thriving and happy, mothers and fathers giving thanks to The Spirit of Love from the Gratitude they feel in their hearts, and the men who hold their heads up and have a new sense of respect for what they are- this is our pay for what we do. 

Keep us in your prayers if you pray, and if you can help with spreading the word about our needs please, we depend on contributions from the public to cover the costs of  operations of Hope Rebirth Homeless Shelter.

Our Website- www.hoperebirthshelter.com

Our email-  hoperebirthhomelessshelter@gmail.com

Like us on Facebook -  

 Hope Rebirth Homeless Shelter Summerville Georgia 30747

story:
Summary

My name is Becca and I own Austin Tie Dye Co. I am 29, a wife, a mother, a daughter, and most importantly a cancer survivor. At 23 year old I was diagnosed with stage III Hodgkin's lymphoma. I underwent 12 rounds of brutal chemo, lost all my hair, gained weight from the medication, and was in great pain for 6 months. Then went through 21 rounds of radiation from which I still have radiation burns. After 5 long years of remission, I was pronounced cured in September 2012. I was lucky. Not only was my cancer "curable," but when I was diagnosed I had no responsibilities and was on my parent's insurance. Like I said, I was lucky.

Life changes when you hear the "C" word. Once you get over the shock of losing your hair, and facing the fact the death is a very real possibility, you are then left thinking about the financial burdon. According to the Live Strong Foundation, chemotherapy can cost up to $30,000 leaving someone without insurance or poor insurance facing a devastating decision: take the drugs to save my life and be in debt for several years, or choose not to take the life saving drugs and lose your life.

This is the project: October is breast cancer awareness month. During the month of October I would like to donate $3 of every pink ribbon tie dyed shirt to Texas Oncology for their Helping Hand's Fund which provides gift cards to a well known local grocery store that can be used for food, prescriptions, gas, or to pay bills. This goes a long way for patients who are spending all their money on medical care or have had to quit or reduce their working hours because of either their treatment or the side effects of their treatment. This is my way of paying it forward. I would like to be able to donate at least $1,500 this year to these patients. 

Why I need your help: Austin Tie Dye Co is a brand new business and to get ready for this great donation drive I am asking for help to get the materials I need. The donations you provide will go toward high quality dyes and the chemicals needed to keep the dye beautiful forever, as well as shirts, and marketing materials to ensure the October Project donation drive is a huge success. 

Thank you so much for your time reading and watching this. You are truly awesome! 

Becca

story:
The Postmiibike is the result of 3 years of R&D and hundreds of successful events worldwide. This campaign is the perfect opportunity to own a simple, reliable and visible photobooth to immortalize any event or souvenir. Need more? Well, did we mention that this photobooth is not only mobile but also customizable at will in a few seconds (both prints and design)? To top it off, by becoming a licensee, you’re also joining a community that will help you grow your business even faster!

Once on the spot, it takes less than a minute to set up your Postmiibike. 

" "Forget old school layout say welcome to magnetic layer! "

 

Abracadabra !

Forget about painfully sticking (and unsticking) stickers and traditional flocking. We’ve developed a magnetic dressing system to customize your Postmiibike, in a few seconds.

 

Let the sun shine !

Never be short of energy  thanks to the solar panel on your Postmiibike’s roof.

      "With its solar panel and battery you can go anywhere and shoot everyday !             Perfect for tourist places, convenient for events" 

you can also use the battery or power outlet when you need. 

 

Two cameras to multiply poses!

Once plugged into the main pole you will be able to ensure hours of shooting in full autonomy.

 

Several secure storage spaces

Let’s be real, this bike really is a mobile photo studio.

Our app is already available in 9 languages and allows your clients to receive a digital version of the printed photo. You can also personalize all your event with our dashboard.

Our “database” of filters and masks is constantly updated. If you have a special need, we can even create custom-made filter or mask.

By joining the Postmii squad, you have access to all the tools we created to successfully run and manage your business. You can easily access all data and personalize your templates in a few clicks!

                    

Get your very own Postmiibike, launch your business and become an exclusive member of the Postmii family! We’ve got your back: our licences include hardware and software for your peace of mind. You can focus on your customers to share love and emotions through personalized photos!

story:
There is nothing a person can ever do to deserve sexual violence. As SlutWalk organizers, we are trying to spread that message and make a positive difference through our actions. We are in our fifth year of an initiative to bring awareness to victim-blaming and rape culture. 

Today 1 in 5 people still think women are asking for sexual assault. People ignore the reality that men face sexual violence too and are often not believed due to the social narrative that men want sex all the time. 

So why is it called SlutWalk? It’s not about wanting to be a slut; it’s about that word being used to discredit victims of sexual abuse for their history, style of clothing or behaviour. If you can prove that a person is a “slut” then you have an excuse to deny their humanity. So if you want to know why it’s a SLUT walk it is because this word is being used to ignore reality, that 80% of victims are being assaulted in their own homes. To learn more about how Slutwalk originated, click here.

Historically, the term “slut” has carried a predominantly negative connotation. Aimed at those who are sexually promiscuous, be it for work or pleasure, it has primarily been women-identified people who have suffered under the burden of this label. The word "slut" has been used in particular to demonize and other the sexuality of women of colour, specifically by colonizers, and as such we recognize that many women may not want to reclaim the term. Whether dished out as a serious indictment of one’s character or merely as a flippant insult, the intent behind slut-shaming is always to wound. 

We’re not standing for that anymore. On August 8th, 2015 we are walking for women to be able to be seen as human beings first and foremost, with ALL victims of sexual assault being seen as deserving of equal protections under the law. 

We believe in working together as a community and a part of that means showing appreciation for the efforts of others. Money isn’t everything, but it is one way we can help those who are helping us. It is important to SlutWalk Edmonton that we are able to pay our speakers and artists for their contributions.

In order to complete this project we need: 

  • Funds to pay our speakers

  • Money going towards food and beverages for the event

  • Monetary donations to cover printing costs, signage and swag 

SlutWalk does not receive any funding from businesses, post-secondary institutions, government or large organizations so we need the support of the community in order to host the event.

We would be most grateful if you could donate to help us implement our project. If you are interested we will keep you informed with regular updates. We look forward to working together for a world free of sexual violence, and a safer, stronger community.
