story:
BE™ is a low-calorie, fiber-rich coffee that mixes completely with cold milk or water. By controlling the serving size, YOU manage the level of flavor, the fiber, and most importantly, the calories. You have the power to create, change, and enjoy your own unique flavor every time. BE™ has been researched and developed by an experienced Italian and French inventor who is passionate about the individual coffee experience.


Your Time is Valuable

Viberation™ Technology eliminates the brewing process, giving you refreshing immediate iced or hot coffee that dissolves completely in seconds. Full diagram description of Viberation™ technology further down in the campaign!



We spent nine years of intensive research and development - starting with a simple idea: How to combine natural flavors and functional benefits, allowing consumers to experience them just the way they wish. We found the answer in our unique protected encapsulation technology, which we originally called EP3 (Encapsulated Powder 3 - Sparkling (whenever needed) + Flavor + Functional benefits).

However, EP3 is much more than just a smart technology, it allows our consumers to take full control over their beverage consumption. They can be the final decision maker on how to use a product and are becoming once more the final designer of the “fabric”. We call it “Viberation™: La Renaissance because it is all about Experience & Inspiration”.

Viberation™ is pure taste, which will stimulate your taste buds, make them vibrate and buzzing with excitement. After consumption we want you just to BE and feel all the positive VIBES released, so we simply called the new product line ViBErant™ in order to link the feeling of simply being with the self-determination of a free creation.

All along this intensive development processes, we validated and confirmed each single step of our innovation with a large community of important US brands and renowned retailers, making sure we will bring to you the most desirable and intriguing product range.









Serge Bueno, founder and executive chairman of Viberation™,
talks about BE™ and all Viberation™ products.









Serge Aaron Bueno

Serge, 57, founder and executive chairman of Viberation™, has been an Inventor, Investor and Serial Entrepreneur since 1984 always in the Marketing field (products and retailers) & Communication businesses. He sold eight companies and launched up to 300 products during his career, which some are still best sellers. The overall story began with the idea of getting rid of PET Bottles, one of the top factors of pollution. As a world average, a bottle will be transported around 1,000km to reach the consumer. The amount of water needed to produce the bottle could be up to six or seven times what's inside the bottle, according to the Water Footprint Network. 15% of the planet is missing water. Lots of wars in the future (and also today) are/would be linked to the lack of water.

Quentin Ducouret

Quentin, 32, started his career in 2006 in a French Venture Capital focused on innovative and tech-savvy startups. In 2007 he joined Initiative & Finance, a French tier-one Private Equity fund investing in SMEs from all sectors and in need of capital for accelerated growth or to smooth a management transition. Quentin enjoys working on ambitious, disruptive ideas and businesses that are led by dynamic and enthusiastic management teams. He became Investment Manager and has built a successful investment track-record. He met Serge in 2013 and they work together since then and is currently the C.F.O of the SDS group. Quentin is a graduate of ESCP Europe and is an alumni of the University of Bath (UK). He is passionate about wine and hiking. With his wife Aude, they are the parents of two children (3 and 1). They reside in Paris, France.

Steven Bueno

Steven, 23, started his professional life in 2014 as a Boeing 737 pilot in a famous north African airline. In 2015, having initially study Management in the prestigious University of Tel Aviv, he decided to join the SDS adventure as the Operations Manager. Steven is interested in all kind of field, this and the fact he lived in five different countries made him very adaptive. He is precise, due to his scientific and aeronautical background, as well as fast learning and ambitious. Being Serge’s son, Steven has been fed his entire life with this entrepreneur spirit.











Risks and Challenges

Like with all entrepreneurial undertakings, there are of course also risks associated with our exiting new projects. Flavor orders being delayed, production mishaps, or scheduling interruptions that delay shipment of finished products, are all real possibilities.

However, we have done our very best to reduce these risks over the last six months. We have our raw materials ready to go, our labels and packaging are designed, and we anticipate no delays. We completed several test runs to find weak spots in our production process and fix them before entering into full production. Our team has numerous years of experience bringing complex products to market and great relationships with our qualified manufacturers, who fully understand the ins and outs of producing our products. We have in addition aligned ourselves with high-quality vendors to ensure all components are delivered on time. All test runs were funded with our own capital beforehand and we are very confident in our abilities to move forward with this project.



FAQ

Where are your raw materials sourced? We source our ingredients from internationally recognized vendors and suppliers, with an exceptional emphasis on quality and excellence.

Do you have experienced in making food products? Our team has numerous years of experience bringing complex products to market, including food products, especially in terms of beverages.

Are your products vegan? We care greatly about the ingredients that we use in our products and only allow the highest quality. Yes, all our products are vegan.

Are your products gluten-free? We care greatly about the ingredients that we use in our products and only allow the highest quality. Yes, all our products are free of gluten.

Are your products free of lactose? We care greatly about the ingredients that we use in our products and only allow the highest quality. Yes, all our products are free of lactose.

Are your products kosher? Our products are manufactures according to the very basic requirements for a kosher certification, meaning no respective animal ingredients, as well as no ingredients containing milk or grapes. However, a certification has not yet been applied for.

Do you ship outside the United States? Yes, shipping is worldwide.

story: Please visit my You Tube Video and our website at www.mentormeinc.com to learn more about our passions, missions, and topics of conversations we have with our clients in the start-up and small business space.

story:
Our Mission!

Penda Health is raising $30,000 to rennovate and operate a new outpatient clinic in Nairobi. The new clinic will provide essential outpatient services, with an emphasis on family planning and women's health, at prices affordable to lower and middle income Kenyans.

Impact!

This clinic, at full capacity, will serve over 30,000 Kenyans a year, and over 1 million Kenyans in 20 years! 

The $30,000 will help Penda buy necessary supplies, such as lab materials, drug stock and raw materials to build and open the clinic and fund 2 clinicians and 2 receptionists for 7 months. After that point, the clinic will be able to sustain itself!

Penda has a proven track record of delivering affordable, high-quality care! We opened our first clinic this February, and have since seen over 1,100 patients. Not only have we catered to a significant amount of patients, but  99% would recommend Penda to a friend!

Moreover, Penda's focus on preventive services, family planning and women's health help us build a healthier Kenya. We empower women to control their family sizes and empower families to control their health. Not only can we improve Kenya's health, but we can help grow Kenya's economy as well by providing jobs and building Kenya's health. 

Help us build a stronger Kenya!

Your Donation

Your donation is essential to help Penda incease access to high quality and affordable healthcare. Check out our infographic for what your donation can help us buy!

Our Business

Penda Health is a social enterprise based out of Kenya that is building a chain of outpatient clinics, with an emphasis on women's health and family planning. Penda targets the lower and middle classes, who have traditionally lacked access to high quality and affordable healthcare. This market is currently served by low quality Hospitalis (typically set up by a lone doctor, nurse or 'quack') or by over-burdened governent clinics.

On the other hand, Penda aims to provide high quality services at affordable prices. Our slogan is "Your Caring Healthcare Provider," and we aim to provide caring and high-quality healthcare that will give each patient a smile after each visit! 

Over the next five years, Penda aims to open over 50 amazing clinics!

Other Ways You Can Help

Don't worry if you can't contribute, you can still help!

  • Help us spread the awareness of Penda's mission and fundraising drive by posting on our facebook wall (https://www.facebook.com/PendaHealth), liking our facebook page, visiting our site (www.pendahealth.com), following our twitter account (@PendaHealth) and inviting friends to do the same!
  • Use the Indiegogo share tools to promote our case!
  • Introduce us to media and fundraising contacts with whom we can build relationships with to further our fundraising goal!

story:
THE PROJECT

If you're a quilter, Quiltfolio is the website you've been waiting for. 

With Quiltfolio you'll be able to track your own projects and fabrics, and easily see what other quilters have done with a particular fabric, pattern, or quilt block. 

You'll be able to find which patterns are in which book and see finished quilts for any pattern (ever wonder what a certain design would look like in prints instead of solids? Or in a light palette instead of dark? We all have!). 

In the fabric section, you'll be able to find what colors a certain print came in, and related prints by color, designer, or collection . . . and much more!

The video above shows you how Ivete, the quilter and programmer behind Quiltfolio, came up with the idea. It also shows you a sneak peek at what's already finished on the site!

Quiltfolio is in active development and is being built by Ivete and her friend Jacinto. We started building Quiltfolio in the middle of April and plan to launch in early June. Here are the features we have planned so far:

  • Fabric searching and "stashing"
  • Project tracking
  • Pattern library
  • Sewing machine info
  • Classifieds section

If you have an idea you want to see us work into the site, please let us know! 

WHY ARE WE FUNDRAISING?

With your support, we'll be able to launch Quiltfolio that much faster! We will be hiring another developer to help us finish the sections of the site that haven't even been started yet. With your help we should be able to launch by mid-July!

PLEDGES

You can pledge as little as $5 or as much as you want. If you pledge at least $15, you'll also get Quiltfolio swag as a reward!

To the right you'll find a list of different levels of pledges that come with rewards. No matter how much you pledge, backers will be the first people invited into the site!

•••••••••••••••••••••••••••••••••••••••••••••••••••••••••••••••••••

PERKS INFO

story_txt:
THE PROJECT
If you're a quilter, Quiltfolio is the website you've been waiting for. 
With Quiltfolio you'll be able to track your own projects and fabrics, and easily see what other quilters have done with a particular fabric, pattern, or quilt block. 
You'll be able to find which patterns are in which book and see finished quilts for any pattern (ever wonder what a certain design would look like in prints instead of solids? Or in a light palette instead of dark? We all have!). 
In the fabric section, you'll be able to find what colors a certain print came in, and related prints by color, designer, or collection . . . and much more!
The video above shows you how Ivete, the quilter and programmer behind Quiltfolio, came up with the idea. It also shows you a sneak peek at what's already finished on the site!
Quiltfolio is in active development and is being built by Ivete and her friend Jacinto. We started building Quiltfolio in the middle of April and plan to launch in early June. Here are the features we have planned so far:

Fabric searching and "stashing"
Project tracking
Pattern library
Sewing machine info
Classifieds section
If you have an idea you want to see us work into the site, please let us know! 
WHY ARE WE FUNDRAISING?
With your support, we'll be able to launch Quiltfolio that much faster! We will be hiring another developer to help us finish the sections of the site that haven't even been started yet. With your help we should be able to launch by mid-July!
PLEDGES
You can pledge as little as $5 or as much as you want. If you pledge at least $15, you'll also get Quiltfolio swag as a reward!
To the right you'll find a list of different levels of pledges that come with rewards. No matter how much you pledge, backers will be the first people invited into the site!

story:
Our Story

Hi there! My name is Tiffany Christner.  I am a wife to a wonderful husband and a mother to two incredible twin boys, who have inspired me to design the Buggy Bench.


After I had my twin boys, I quickly realized how much I had to depend on others to help me do things.  I remember lying in bed one night wondering how I was going to go to the store the next day to get my food.  Not only did I worry about one of them falling out, but there was no place to put the groceries, and you can only fit so much under the cart.  I absolutely despise using the stretch-limo sized carts that are hard to maneuver and difficult to find at some stores.


I began thinking of how I could keep my second child safe and seated in the cart. Not only for the convenience of shopping, but for the safety of my child.  Fact is, an average of 20,000 children go to the emergency room each year from falling out of carts!


I knew I had to think of something to help me and all the other moms out there with 2 or more children. Which brought me to design the buggy bench.  Itâ€™s nice to know that I can get my shopping done with my twin boys being safely seated in the cart.



Safety For All Children

The great thing about the Buggy Bench is that it is not for just twins!  I see moms all the time with their toddlers in the basket of the cart and their babies buckled in the front or vice versa.  The Buggy Bench can also be used if you have one child.  Germs cover the shopping carts that your little one is touching, the buggy bench can be used and washed whenever needed.


It is designed to conveniently fit into your diaper bag, and more importantly, to make your out of the house experience more enjoyable.  From one mom to the next, trust me, you wonâ€™t be disappointed!


What We Need & What You Get

We were lucky enough to find Chris in our town to get started.  He did the heavy lifting with ensuring the product was of good quality, helping with the patent, the video, the website and general business advice.  From here, it is on us to market my story and get the product in production.  While Chris 's company helped with a lot we are still responsible for meeting the production requirements.


We are asking you to help us with meeting our initial production orders and getting enough material and components to get us through our first 180 units of production.


Other Ways You Can Help

Please continue to help in these ways


Pinterest - Please pin the BuggyBench on your Pinterest board and help talk about it. 


Facebook - Please share with your friends


Blog - Please blog anything you can do to help educate mothers on this amazing product


Walmart - We entered the "Get on the Shelf" contest, you can vote for us here; http://www.getontheshelf.com/product/2803/Buggy...


Thank you all for helping make the Buggy Bench a reality!!

story:
Our Story

Two moms, two friends, one dream.  Liz and Michelle started Sweet Charity Thrift Boutique in March 2011 to provide previously loved clothing and accessories for woman who want to look great at affordable prices and feel good about their purchase.

Sweet Charity Thrift Boutique also sells handcrafted items by local artists to support our local community.  Some of the products we sell are soy wax candles, natural pantry items, handcrafted jewelry, photography, hand sewn friendly monsters out of recycled clothes, greeting cards, tutus, hair accessories and fairy wings.

Sweet Charity Thrift Boutique is committed to giving a significant portion of their profits to Imagine Goods, a non-profit that serves the marginalized and vulnerable in Cambodia. Imagine Goods also supports a Safe Haven where formerly trafficked ladies are taught to sew enabling them to be given a fair wage for their  work and break the cycle of poverty.  Some of these products include bags, tablecloths, napkins, aprons, clutches and dresses. 

Michelle travels to Cambodia twice a year overseeing the design and making of this project and returns with these products to sell at Sweet Charity Thrift Boutique.

Sweet Charity also partners with Imagine Goods to prevent trafficking by raising funds for building toilets, drilling clean water wells and providing formula for babies with HIV+ mothers.  We do this by having special promotional days like Well Wednesdays, Formula Fridays, Sanitation Saturdays and 50% of Sunday sales go to these Imagine Goods' projects.



The Impact

We are currently in a one way street, back in a corner in a difficult to find location.  We were given the opportunity to move to a high traffic, tourist area on a main street in a much bigger building.  In this new location we will be able to expand our local artist room, add children's clothing and accessories and carry more products made by the ladies in Cambodia. 


What We Need & What You Get

We will use ALL  the money raised to pay for security deposit, more racks, shelving, paint, mannequins, hangers, office supplies and signage for the new store ready for us to move in March 2012.  


Other Ways You Can Help

Please spread the word and share this link with your family, friends and co-workers.  Check out our website www.sweetcharityshop.com and FaceBook: Sweet Charity Thrift Boutique.  Stop by our new location 21West Main Street Strasburg, Pa  set to open (WITH YOUR HELP)  March 2012

story:
Our Story

With over ten years of vacationing and traveling extensively throughout Costa Rica, Joe and Gina Downes are pleased to offer their unique perspective of this beautiful country with AWAY WE GO- COSTA RICA TOURS.

AWAY WE GO combines the rare natural beauty of Costa Rica with worry free escorted travel.  Over the years, our Costa Rica adventures have taken us down the road less traveled.  Choosing towns and villages more for their beauty and uniqueness rather than their tourism trade, staying in small family owned hotels rather than Americanized “all inclusive” compounds, and dining in locally owned and operated restaurants-enjoying the fresh regional bounty offered. Getting off the beaten path to truly experience the real Costa Rica is the AWAY WE GO experience.

When exploring this alluring country with us as your guides, you will experience breathtaking waterfalls, gaze at behemoth volcanoes, and explore pristine beaches. You will discover the beauty of Costa Rica ’s National Parks, enjoy the thrill of zip lining through the lush canopy of the rainforest, and enjoy a relaxing soak in the natural volcanic hot springs . Expect to be awestruck by scenic vistas, spectacular churches, and savor amazing authentic cuisine – you’ll see it all, and meet a lot of friendly folks along the way. We offer our clients a travel experience that will last a lifetime, while creating repeat customers and a wealth of referrals.

The Impact

In creating AWAY WE GO-COSTA RICA TOURS we intend to share our love and extensive knowledge of this beautiful country with travelers that want an authentic experience. All too often, we have seen “foreigners” come to Costa Rica and never actually experience Costa Rica!  Tourists are picked up from the airport and whisked away to an “all inclusive” compound never to be seen or heard from again.  Our unique perspective on vacationing in Costa Rica is to take small groups of customers and their referrals on personalized, authentic journeys to experience the true beauty and adventure of Costa Rica.  We already have a healthy list of satisfied clients who are referring us to their friends. At this point we are fielding inquires and doing our best to keep up with the interest that is organically growing by word-of-mouth about our personalized tours. Because of natural interest and continued inquires all the signals are pointing to us taking this to the next level.

We are not "ecotourism", nor are we “budget” travel, and we don’t do “extreme”. What AWAY WE GO offers is a comfortable, casual, and authentic trip around Costa Rica that fits the time frame available. Our focus in starting Away We Go - Costa Rica Tours is to share an overview of the country with first time visitors: those that may be feeling a little out of their comfort zone in a foreign land and not fully aware of all the right places to see, be and experience. And at the end of the journey our guests leave with an appreciation of this beautiful foreign land, its culture, and its people.

 

What We Need & What You Get

At this point in the AWAY WE GO project, we have contracted a fleet of three vehicles, each to accomodate different size groups.  The largest vehicle is able to take up to 10 passengers per tour. We have established firm relationships with six “home base” hotels. We’ve solidified partnerships with restaurants and excursion operators for specialty pricing and preferential treatment of our guests. Over the years, we have mapped the most scenic, entertaining, and least stressful tour routes for our customer’s maximum enjoyment.

We are now at a critical point in taking this project from concept to company. To ensure success we need a creative and dynamic website with relative links and SEO/SEM optimization. For clients that request printed pieces we’ll need a compelling brochure, we’d prefer printable PDF brochures off the site but there are still some folks that want literature through the mail. We are aware of the huge value of social media, after all we have a ground swell of interest from word-of-mouth, and will utilize Facebook, Twitter and Youtube out of the gate as well as choosing the proper media mixture within the tourism industry to promote the project.

To that end, we have teamed with MAD-WIT, found on the web at www.Mad-Wit.com - a young, hungry, creative marketing team poised to put AWAY WE GO - COSTA RICA TOURS on the map. The majority of this Indiegogo crowd funding campaign will go to development of our brand and unique travel experience through electronic and traditional marketing avenues.

 

Other Ways You Can Help

You can help us to reach our goals by asking your friends to support our project! Email your friends, share on Facebook and Twitter, and ask your friends to do the same! Maybe you know of someone looking for a trip to paradise.  Please let them know about us, our website, and our project!  Many thanks for your time and effort.

story:
Hi Everyone,

My name is Ania Maj and my husband Marcin and I have decided to create this fundraiser to hopefully raise whatever funds we can to help those that need it the most. We live in Rifle, Colorado and run a family operated Motel and even though we're "safe" at the moment and not in any immediate danger of the High Park Fire or the "Monster" Waldo Canyon Fire it breaks our hearts to watch the news and see all the videos and pictures of homes destroyed, devastated families that had lost everything they had. We would also like to donate the funds to several Animal Hospitals and shelters in need of funds to be able to support large and small pets that are being affected by the wildfires and being boarded at various facilities. It's important to us that you participate in this campaign and help in any way you can, it'll be greatly appreciated. Even if we don't reach our goal the funds WILL go to participating and legitimate institutions helping those who are affected.

If you can't contribute, don't worry!

Please share this campaign and spread the word, let's do everything we can to help!

story:
Help Us Provide Direct Support to Victims of the Ebola Crisis in Sierra Leone

We seek to raise funds to send to a remarkable Sierra Leonean man. He is standing by to provide support to those who are most vulnerable to Ebola. All he needs is financial assistance.

The Rev. Moses Frederick Khanu is a minister in the Wesleyan Church of Sierra Leone. He lives and works in Makeni, Sierra Leone’s fourth-largest city. Rev. Khanu is the Assistant Head of his church in Makeni and supervises church activities in six districts.

Moses is working with orphans, quarantined families and survivors to offer vital support. We've already started to help him increase his efforts within his vast community. With your help Moses and his team of ministers and volunteers can help save the lives of children and bring dignity back into the lives of Ebola victims. This crisis is escalating. People are terrified. Your contribution will have immediate impact. We know you will help Moses. 

Rev. Khanu is not just a minister. He also has advanced training in research and gender studies. He has researched the situation of widows and girl mothers following Sierra Leone’s civil war, as well as the victims of female genital mutilation. Rev. Khanu describes his life mission as follows: “As a minister, my greatest burden in life is to fight against injustice that women and children encounter in society and to care for vulnerable people.”

Here is how Rev. Khanu describes the situation facing people in the Makeni area of Sierra Leone: “The most vulnerable category of persons include: Those who have contracted the disease; People in quarantined homes; Children and widows of the deceased; and Persons who have recovered from the disease. All of these people need financial support. To raise money for this people will be great. I can receive this money on their behalf and disburse it accordingly.”

Rev. Khanu has been a friend and research colleague of Marc Sommers since 2005. Many times in the field, I have witnessed his gift for communicating empathy and inspiring trust with underclass Sierra Leoneans, including former boy and girl child soldiers, prostitutes and other outcast youth.

Now he needs our help. Urgently

The Ebola Situation in Mekeni, Sierra Leone

A week ago, Rev. Khanu describes the situation in Makeni in the following way: “Of all Districts in Sierra Leone, Makeni has the fifth-highest number of people infected with Ebola. There are 106 confirmed cases, 29 probable cases, 43 deaths, 37 probable deaths and 7 who have been fully treated and have survived the virus.”  It is likely that these numbers are in reality much higher. People are hiding family member who contract the disease and not reporting deaths for fear of reprisals and stigma, which can affect their ability to get food and essential commodities to live.

Moses went on to say:

“Although every effort has been put in place to the Ebola situation, many challenges remain. They include:

·  Denial/Ignorance. This is the biggest challenge. Many affected communities and homes associate Ebola with witchcraft. In a nearby village where 40 died in a week, survivors contended that sorcery, not Ebola, caused the deaths. This militated against any preventive measures. A similar response arose in a Makeni neighborhood after seven people died on a recent Sunday. There are many other cases as well. More effort is needed to fight against the denial and increase awareness among the people.

·  Inadequate Support to Quarantined Homes. After a home is quarantined due to Ebola infection, food is supplied to household members. Unfortunately, the food often is inadequate. There even have been allegations that some people, especially children, dying because of starvation.

·  Inadequate Hand Washing Materials. Hand washing is the greatest preventive measure against Ebola infection. To do this properly, people require rubber gloves, soap and chlorine. However, most homes and public centers do have these materials.

·  The High Cost of Living. Shutdowns across the country because of Ebola has caused the prices of essential commodities is skyrocket. This makes it very difficult for people to cope.

·  Stigma after Discharge from Hospitals. Some infected persons have recovered from the disease and have been discharged from hospital. Unfortunately, such persons have not been accepted back in their homes and communities. They seem to be stigmatized, and are treated like pariahs. Finding a source of livelihood for such people is difficult.

·  Care for Orphans and Widows. There is no organized intervention to care for the orphans and widows of people who have died from Ebola. Providing care and support to them is a serious challenge.”

How the funds will be used

We seek to raise at least $2,000 – hopefully much more – to send to Rev. Khanu. He is how he intends to use the funds we send to him: “The most urgent need is providing food to those in quarantined homes, hand washing materials, and support to widows, orphans and those who have recovered from the disease.”

Please give what you can – and check in for reports on how your money is spent

Let’s all contribute funds so that people victimized by Ebola swiftly receive our support. In the words of Rev. Khanu: “I will do my utmost to ensure that the intended purpose of the money is met. Please extend to those who will be contributing my sincere thanks and appreciation. God bless them all. I will document and send reports on how the money is spent.”

We will post reports here from Rev. Khanu when they arrive.

People are terrified. Your contribution will have immediate impact. We know you will help Moses.

story:
Short Summary

I am running this fund raising campaign to help my son, Darius, along with two of his high school friends, Jose (17) & Elijah (17), establish their own home based business.

While on summer break, Darius (14), has expressed on several occasions that he wanted to make money to buy his own clothes and shoes, as well as cover the cost associated with playing high school football.  The cost for equipment alone is $645.  So instead of asking mom and dad to pay for all this out of their pockets, he'd like to earn his own money to pay for his equipment, gear and clothes to begin his first year of high school.

With football work-outs already underway and two-a-days quickly approaching, he is extremely short on time and will require most of his equipment, especially his helmet ($275) in the next coming weeks.  

Jose and Elijah (Eli) are both entering their senior year of high school have also expressed their desires to create income for themselves for similar reasons, but more so to prepare for college and life after high school.

After giving Darius and his partners some options on ways to earn money, they have decided against working at the typical places most teens their age work and would like to start their own business.  They loved the thought of being entrepreneurs and the time freedom it will afford them in pursuing their dreams!  

After doing some careful and diligent research, we found a company that will allow them the opportunity to market and promote healthy premium, high in demand products to their peers and friends. They have already created a customer base and a small following of friends who have committed support in purchasing products from them as soon as they're up and running. 

What We Need & What You Get

To get their business started, they simply need inventory:

  • $1,600 will provide enough capital to purchase the necessary inventory to  fulfill all pre-orders, as well as any new orders. 
  • Website and marketing tools are included.
  • Any and all funds raised will be used to purchase inventory, just at a smaller amount if goal is not accomplished.
  • Any and all amount contributed are highly appreciated, but please be generous. 
  • You can be proud of the fact that your contribution assisted in these young men achieve financial freedom at an early age. 
  • You're teaching these young men to fish for a lifetime, not feeding them fish for a day. (always wanted to use that analogy in something) 
  • You also have the opportunity to earn free product!

The Impact

Your contribution will certainly allow these young men to become entrepreneurs, independent and successfully in achieving their goals of obtaining all the necessities for the school year and their love of football.

Risks & Challenges

  • Since they have already taken pre-orders, though small, they are already off to a good start in being profitable.
  • Risk are very small as these products are in high demand with their peers. They have already receive request for more orders and they haven't sold one item yet. 
  • If customers aren't happy with the product, the company has a full money back guarantee.  Which means they owe nothing for returned products.

Other Ways You Can Help

If you're unable to contribute financially, you can certainly help by getting the word out and sharing with your family and friends:

  • Please share this campaign with those that you know.

story:
I wanted to name this: "For Years, I've Helped You With Your S***, Now You Can Help Me With Mine…Help Fund Our Septic System!", because I thought the play on words was funny.  Also, it reminded me that we are all in this together.  We are all together in this spinning ball called Earth and we all need each other.

Scott and I have had a dream of creating a place, a community where artists and seekers can come and stay to unwind and recover from the fast-paced intensity of life.  We found five magnificent acres in Bastrop County, about 50 miles east of Austin.  For those of you who look out your windows and see tall pines and other trees, you might not understand the significance of this area.  This area is an anomaly in that ancient Loblolly Pines grow here in Central Texas.  They are so majestic and beautiful!  Anyway, we were able to afford it because it has a collapsed house on it.  We are in the midst of clearing all of the junk and will put two small cabins on the property-one for us and one to share.  It will also have several porches as a communal gathering place.

We have managed to secure funding for most of it but are short of money for the septic system.  No lie; I couldn't make this up if I tried.  We had NO idea they could be so expensive!  

So, in the vein that we are all here to help each other, I am asking for your help in creating this rural utopia.  Imagine a place where artists can come create, draw, paint, write…  Imagine a place where people can come meditate and harmonize with nature…  Imagine a place where one can just be.  Hop on a bike, hike the nearby woods, write in your journal, paint on your canvas, weave on your loom, the possibilities are endless.   It's an artist retreat, a  weekend getaway, a spiritual workshop, a writer's camp;  in essence, a place that allows one to feel recharged and peaceful.  We all need a special place and we hope our cabins will be just that.

The name of the project is in jest but our vision of the land is genuine.  

 Thank you for your consideration.  And please pass this on, if you are so inclined.

Lisa & Scott

story:
About ThinkOfPhilippines.org

ThinkOfPhilippines.org was originally founded with the purpose of helping feed the hungry children of Polillo Island in the Philippines, with potential to branch out to other regions in distress.

 

What Is Needed

Our first large goal is to raise $10,000 which will directly aid in supplying the needs of the Feeding Program.  The feeding program assists feeding children who are orphans or those who do not have the basic necessities of day-to-day living.

 

Your Impact

For every $1 you contribute, you help provide a meal for a hungry child.

For every $3 you contribute, you provide a child with food for a whole day.

For every $20 you contribute, you provide a child with food for an entire week.

Your contributions can go a long way in helping relieve hunger in the Philippines.

story:
This Campaign is about a family dear to our hearts.  Katie and Lucio Lara are parents to 4 year old twins, Miguel and Olivia. Katie died in a single automobile accident on July 3, 2012.  She was 25 years old.  She was rushing home, seatbelt on, for Lucio to have the truck for work. Their only vehicle was totaled, liability insurance only.  Katie did not have life insurance.  Like many, Katie and her family lived paycheck to paycheck. Unlike many, this family has little family support.  Lucio works 50+ hrs each week as a landscaper, without health insurance.  Fortunately, the twins are able to receive state health insurance.  They are "just" overincome for food stamps, childcare assistance, etc.  At this time, the family is in need of a vehicle for Lucio to go to work, assistance to help pay for the children's care while Lucio works (they have one more year until full-day kindergarten), rent until he returns to work (Lucio does not get "paid time off") , utilities, food and many other basic needs.

 My sister and I first met Katie 12 years ago. She was best friends with our cousins. She became our family when we realized how much Katie needed a family when her mom died when Katie was 15 years old.  

 My sister, Laura, became Katie's "2nd mom".  Laura filled the roles of mother/aunt/grandma/'big sister' with a smile, support and love. 

 Katie met a man she described as "the greatest". Lucio can easily be described as patient, kind, caring, supportive, hardworking, thoughtful.  My family measures greatness in others by the kindness of their soul. Lucio is great.

 

 

 

How the Funds Will Be Used:

Immediate needs include a vehicle for Lucio, childcare when he is at work, rent until Lucio is receiving paychecks and basic needs.

Should amount received exceed needs, an account will be established for Miguel and Olivia.

 

Other Ways You Can Help:

Please share this page with anyone you possibly can.

Please let us know of any agencies and/or support groups that may help this family.

We will be contacting Friends Way at http://www.friendsway.org for the twins and Lucio.

story:
A bit about Us

  My sister Mackenzie and I, Samantha, both current university students are partnering with the Oneida first Baptist Church on the Oneida native settlement near London Ontario to offer a summer camp to youth and programs for young adults during the upcoming summer.  I have worked and volunteered at Oneida over the past two years and feel strongly that many of the children’s needs in the community can be met through a safe and fun camp environment.  By hiring Oneida teenagers and young adults as camp counsellors the need for jobs is also being addressed.  This group of young and passionate youth will be integral in creating a camp environment that meets the unique cultural needs of the native community and offers children an experience they have not been afforded in the past. 

   Donations will help cover the school rental fees, the food for the daily programs, the craft and sport supplies that will enhance the program, the counsellors’ pay and also the cost of bussing students to the school from across the settlement.  The cost of sponsoring a child to attend camp for one full week is $35.00. My work at Oneida has led me to meet the most loveable group of children that are simply hungry for fun and interaction, and they flock to youth night or the one week of SPARC camp where they know this is a promise.  I would simply like to offer them these experiences every week of the summer, not just one.

Our vision

  To run camp the way we envision it would mean securing the school on the settlement as a location for our programs, bussing the children to and from the school, feeding everyone breakfast and lunch, and offering a salary to our hired Oneida young adult counsellors.  This wish list is costly, requiring seven thousand dollarsto run 4 full weeks of camp for 50 kids. The more accessible we can make camp and the more needs we can meet in the community be it the need for safety, for food, for fun or for a job, the more valuable the initiative becomes to the community.  Partnering with prominent figures within the Oneida community, the principal of Standing Stone Elementary School, the leaders of the Oneida First Baptist Church and some Band Council Members, this is an initiative that the community supports and welcomes.  Children have a right to have their physical, developmental, emotional and spiritual needs met, and your donations to help run summer camp at Oneida will help us achieve that. 

What you get for your Support 

  We are looking to raise $750 dollars through this campaign, money that will be used to acquire a bus to transport kids to and from camp.  We are diligently seeking other avenues to cover the other associated costs, but for donating through our campaign on Indiegogo there are perks you can claim as a thank you for your support. For donations of 35 dollars perhaps you’d like a picture for your fridge drawn by the child you've been able to send to camp, or a friendship bracelet crafted during one of our camp activities. We will also send you a personalized thank you card if you would like for any donation amount.

The Impact

  Whether you have been to summer camp or not many would probably agree that some of our fondest childhood memories take place in settings that encourage fun, play, friendships and new experiences.  Summer camp at Oneida will provide a safe environment for children while their parents work, will foster positive relationships with peers and role models, and will encourage learning through half days of activities that develop language and literacy skills.  Similar to the youth nights we currently run once a month for the youth grade four and up, there will be an endless amount of games and sports, crafts and drama games, meals provided daily and character building conversations and activities that will translate much further than the two months of summer camp.  Since beginning at Oneida two summers ago I have seen enrollment nearly double to eighty children at the one week camp run by SPARC, a summer camp I worked as a manager at in 2011 and 2012.  At Oneida there is a need, there is a desire and there are countless children who desire nothing more than a chance to experience camp like many children in the GTA are privileged enough to have within minutes of their homes.

Other ways You can Help out

  With an initiative like this there are so many ways to get involved past financial donations.   Perhaps you have the means to make a donation of food, or of craft supplies.  Perhaps you have time to canvas around local business and organizations to ask for their consideration of supporting our efforts to bring camp to Oneida.  Just as important, you may have the time to spread the word about our campaign.  Social media sites are great ways to do so, and Indiegogo provides share tools to do so.  Word of mouth is just as appreciated.  However you are able to help make our initiative a reality and help us bring camp to Oneida is appreciated!

We will also send you a personalized thank you card if you would like for any donation amount.
The Impact
  Whether you have been to summer camp or not many would probably agree that some of our fondest childhood memories take place in settings that encourage fun, play, friendships and new experiences.  Summer camp at Oneida will provide a safe environment for children while their parents work, will foster positive relationships with peers and role models, and will encourage learning through half days of activities that develop language and literacy skills.  Similar to the youth nights we currently run once a month for the youth grade four and up, there will be an endless amount of games and sports, crafts and drama games, meals provided daily and character building conversations and activities that will translate much further than the two months of summer camp.  Since beginning at Oneida two summers ago I have seen enrollment nearly double to eighty children at the one week camp run by SPARC, a summer camp I worked as a manager at in 2011 and 2012.  At Oneida there is a need, there is a desire and there are countless children who desire nothing more than a chance to experience camp like many children in the GTA are privileged enough to have within minutes of their homes.
Other ways You can Help out
  With an initiative like this there are so many ways to get involved past financial donations.   Perhaps you have the means to make a donation of food, or of craft supplies.  Perhaps you have time to canvas around local business and organizations to ask for their consideration of supporting our efforts to bring camp to Oneida.  Just as important, you may have the time to spread the word about our campaign.  Social media sites are great ways to do so, and Indiegogo provides share tools to do so.  Word of mouth is just as appreciated.  However you are able to help make our initiative a reality and help us bring camp to Oneida is appreciated!

story:
Welcome Supports and Lovers of Great Stories

I can't tell you how thankful I am to my Creator for granting me the innate ability to express.  Through that expression I have found my passion for film writing.  August 2014 Abike Talent Company was launched.  I didn't just want to be a screenwriter.  I wanted to express through both the film & publishing industries.

I'm honored to say that I have just finished my first draft for Close Call. It's an original screenplay about a 17 year old young lady who starts dating a 38 year old man.  Through this guy, she meets two of his friends who are also in their 30's and  are in a dysfunctional relationship.  The young lady's life is turned upside down when she's arrested for the murder of a 15 year old girl.  She soon realizes she has one of  the most valuable life lessons to learn.  Will she learn?

For a sample of my writing visit, www. abiketalentcompany.wordpress.com It's a creative pitch tool for my Indiegogo  startup campaign.  My goal is to raise funds for startup costs, not only as a film writer, but also to cover startup expenses for  written content and creative design of greeting cards.  The funds will also be used for a laptop, print costs, travel for meetings and other business related expenses.

    Did You Say Perks? I got U!

    To kindly thank you for your contributions. I will provide special perks to each contributor that will "perk" you up!  My campaign goal is to raise $3,500. Of course, I wouldn't want to leave you out for your time, patience and support.  Remember, it's up to you what you choose to contribute.

    The Impact

    Honestly, there are three things that got me started on this journey to start my own small business: a passion for storytelling, a passion for film and a passion to make sure that people get entertaining, yet quality content.

    I truly believe that writers are storytellers and teachers at heart.  Writers don't just write for profit, they really do write to make an impact.  In my specialty it's film. Writers are like astronaut, they go outer space and come back to the world and share their experience, knowledge, wisdom, creativity and most of all their passion.

    It's like an astronaut who goes out of space, explore and comes back with proof to show the world that beautiful worlds exsist out there.

    I choose to make an impact with my work by making sure I provide quality content and images that are bearable upon the human conscious. To create such contents that cause us to ask questions in today's society dealing with relevant issues that often go overlooked, making our communities and country as a whole stagnant.


    Risks & Challenges

    All writers have challenges to overcome.  Mine are at this moment:

    • Startup expenses and good valuable connections in the industry.
    • With every valuable resource and contact, I plan to network, make a connection, plus build and maintain a business realtionships.  I will use the contributions for startup expenses, marketing and promotion.

    Other Ways You Can Help

    Some people just can't contribute, but that doesn't mean they can't help:

    • Please get the word out and feel free to post my campaign link on any media outlet.  Also, share by word of mouth.   We need good stories in the market, so don't be shy!
    • Please refer any professionals in the industry that may be looking for a good story to my Wordpress blog @ www.abiketalentcompany.wordpress.com 
    • Make it easy by using the Indiegogo share tools.

story:
BACKGROUND INFORMATION

About me:
My name is Tomás Dietz. I’m Australian born; a flamenco dancer/teacher by profession. I have Scottish, German and Motu heritage. I'm 50 years of age, and live in Sydney, Australia.

My story points to the Motu people, the tribes which inhabit 13 villages in the narrow tropical savannah region of Central Province, Papua New Guinea.

My Motu descent is through my mother, Hane Igua Hila, a Motuan from Hanuabada village. My mum is fiercely proud of her ancient heritage and the cultural traditions that are part of her direct experience. In her youth she watched her grandmother making clay cooking-pots on her lap; she was transitioned from wearing grass skirts every day to wearing cotton dresses; and she bears the traditional body tattoos of her people.

Although I’m proudly born and raised Australian, I also deeply treasure my Motu ancestry and am fortunate to have been brought up bi-lingual and bi-cultural.

My concerns:
Sadly, mum’s culture has been seriously eroded since it was first exposed to foreign influence over 100 years ago. Ever since then the Motu have grown to de-value their ancient cultural practices. But they've lost enough. They need to re-value the knowledge and skills they've refined over thousands of years that are now on the brink of extinction. They need to believe that traditional practices can co-exist with modern lifestyles, or even to evolve with them. If work like mine is left much longer I fear this will very soon lead to irreversible cultural loss as elders who know the details die out. Cultural loss has a profound impact on the social fabric of a people.

I cannot sit and watch this culture die off.  I have the commitment and drive to bring about change - all I need is community funds to enable my planned work.


This is what inspired my initiative - the project I've called, 'GIDA'.

'Gida' is the Motu word for ‘embers’, implying that the cultural traditions that have subsided to embers can either be left to die down to cold coals, or actively fanned back into flame.



SPECIFIC FOCUS FOR THIS PROJECT: MOTU POTTERY

Many aspects of traditional Motu culture are endangered (eg the language, herbal medicine, children’s games etc), and they are all interlinked somehow, but the most urgent need is to save the endangered pottery tradition from extinction.

Mrs Boio Moi is the last surviving potter in Boera (one of the 13 Motu villages). She embodies the final connection to the practice. The need to save her knowledge is critical, not just for Motu people, but for the bank of knowledge and achievement that is the heritage of all humans.


WHY IS POTTERY REVIVAL SUCH A BIG DEAL?

There are many ways that the revival of Motu pottery can contribute to overall cultural well-being:

• To empower women by establishing a Women’s Pottery Society managed by women, the traditional caretakers of the industry, returning to them the status that was once their birthright.

• Village workshops will be established through the Pottery Society, for women to teach traditional pottery skills.

• Intercultural opportunities exist for non-Motuans to attend such workshops, which can be developed to include broader Motu village experiences, such as family stays or traditional fishing expeditions.

• Pots made at the workshops can be marketed for sale and exhibited in galleries as Motu works of art - existing outlets will be enriched, and new outlets can be created.

• Youth will be specifically targeted and involved, as I plan to negotiate the introduction of Motu pottery into the school curriculum; their involvement with pottery production at home will also give them a strong sense of inclusion, identity and pride in the village context.

• A TV programme of inspired cookery and nutrition will be launched to encourage the use of non-toxic traditional cooking-pots as desirable and preferable to aluminium pots.

• Attendant small business will emerge - for instance clay collection, processing and supply.

• I envisage the revival of traditional trade partnerships, for example with the Kerema people of the Gulf who traditionally traded sago and other goods in exchange for Motu pottery - this was the former Hiri trade event carried out via lagatoi boats, but today this could be interpreted by motor boat or land vehicles, opening up entrepreneurial avenues for transportation/cargo businesses.

• I also see the creation of an annual Motu Pottery Festival in villages featuring thatch stalls where potters exhibit and sell their wares to tourists amid traditional feasting and celebration. The reliable influx of visitors will provide opportunities for villagers to sell a diverse range of items, eg craft goods and Motu food.

These are just some ideas which also encourage the preservation of other traditional practices such as singing and dancing, traditional jewellery and adornment.

The scope is enormous, and the potential for social repair and empowerment is immeasurable.



WHAT WE NEED:

Budget: AUD$31,370
This will enable me to take a small team of four people (2 researchers + 2 technicians) from Sydney to Boera for a month to document the details of Motu pottery construction, and to record the oral history of Mrs Boio Moi. I will produce a two video documentaries: one, a short general interest video, and the other a detailed technical video for training purposes for use in Gida's implementation programmes. I will also prepare a written report for submission to PNG research authorities and UNESCO.

Fixed Expenses:
  1. Airfares and transfers (airfares are economy return Sydney/Port Moresby);
  2. Visas;
  3. Budget accommodation in Port Moresby and in Boera;
  4. Materials & equipment (video/stills camera, voice recorder)
  5. Hire of vehicle for local fieldwork.

Variable Expenses:
  1. Essential living expenses (food/incidentals);
  2. Remuneration for Mrs Moi;
  3. Goodwill gifts for local helpers;
  4. Petrol (gasoline) for Fieldwork vehicle;
  5. Data storage cards;
  6. Stationery supplies;
  7. Telephone costs.

The Research Team will comprise:
   1.  Project Manager
   2.  Field Assistant
   3.  Videographer
   4.  Photographer


WHAT DO YOU GET FROM DONATING?
There are several perk options for specific donation amounts, but more importantly, you are participating in the salvation of ancient knowledge.
You are contributing directly to the well-being of a vulnerable people.
They may never meet you, but you have their deepest gratitude, along with mine.


WHAT WILL THE TEAM ACTUALLY DO IN BOERA?

Our objectives are:

  1. To record every aspect of Motu pottery production as known to Mrs Boio Moi, by means of photography and video documentary filming;
  2. To interview Mrs Moi and record her oral history;
  3. To identify ways to revive the relevance of pottery to Motu people;
  4. To identify outlets for Motu pottery beyond the village environment to offer village potters potential sources of additional income and give further incentive for them to maintain production;
  5. To investigate the possibility to revive traditional trading partnerships, eg with the Kerema people (traditionally the Motu people traded their pots for sago and other produce from the Kerema people in the more fertile Gulf area). This would rekindle inter-village bonds, improve their diet and health, and gain more control of their own destiny and well-being, and allow other villages to once again enjoy the benefits of cooking with traditional pots;
  6. Project Team Members who will facilitate the delivery of future village workshops will learn how to make Motu pots, so that they’re better able to motivate others to learn and ensure the longevity of the revival;
  7. To collate the findings from this research into formats that the general public can access easily and freely, eg videos that can be kept in libraries.
  8. To enter traditional pottery skills into the school curriculum at primary, secondary and tertiary levels.

GENERAL INTEREST VIDEO:
The film material will be used to create to a human interest programme for the broader community via television. Already SBS TV Australia journalists have expressed the desire to be involved. This represents a significant support to our work in terms of public awareness.


TECHNICAL VIDEO:
Specific skills & techniques to be filmed for teaching programmes:

  1. Identifying and collecting natural clay at source;
  2. Identifying and collecting the correct sand for temper;
  3. Sorting of the clay;
  4. Collecting seawater;
  5. Adding seawater to the clay;  
  6. Kneading;
  7. Clay pug formation;
  8. Initial wall construction by hand;
  9. Wall construction by anvil/paddle technique;
  10. Lip construction;
  11. Surface finishing;
  12. Drying;
  13. Baking (firing) - fire construction and addition of greenware pots, temperature control;
  14. Handling tongs construction and usage;
  15. Tool making and usage, eg anvil and paddle, tools of decoration;
  16. Decoration traditions, eg etching of tattoo designs, shell indentations.


Where do the funds go if we don't reach our entire goal? 
If funds don't initially reach the entire goal, the Research Team will either be reduced accordingly, and/or the expenses will be further pared down, or the funds will be held while fundraising continues until sufficient funds have been raised to send the team to Boera Village.

Where do the funds go if there is surplus?
Surplus funds will be directed into the Boera project as needed in the field work and later for the implenentation programmes, and also invested for use in future Gida projects. Gida's work is enormous, and does not end with the Boera Pottery project.

What happens to the equipment that is bought for this project?
Equipment is an investment for use in all future Gida Fieldwork.


The Impact of your involvement:
This project has enormous and long lasting benefit for the social fabric of the Motu people. Your contributions will directly help to rescue ancient human traditions and enrich the lives and culture of thousands of people.  The knowledge you're helping to save is significant not just for Motu people, but for the bank of knowledge and achievement that is the heritage of all humans on this planet.



RISKS & CHALLENGES TO THE PROJECT:

The main hurdle is finding funds. This project is privately driven and non-profit.  I do not yet have sponsorship from large corporations and organisations. Without funding this project cannot move forward.

Solution to the funding problem?
The global community - you can help directly. Indiegogo Crowd Funding can quickly involve people from all over the planet, such as yourself, to mobilise this important project.


Another challenge in this area is emotional commitment to detail.
Academics tend to record such cultural expressions in general terms and concepts for books and articles.

What's the answer to commitment?
Me! I'm personally and deeply committed as a passionate Motuan. I have insight into the culture and speak the language, so I'll attend to recording every detail and nuance because it's meaningful to me and all Motuans - it's the only way for living cultural knowledge to be passed on to the next generation.


Other Ways You Can Help:
If you can’t contribute with funds, you can still help by spreading the word - your friends and workmates may be willing to help. They too can help spread the word, and maybe this way my quest will find its way to UNESCO or other humanitarian organisations who can support my quest.

Please, use the Indiegogo share tools at the top of the page.
Thank you for your support - Tomás.

======================================================
FURTHER SOURCES OF INFORMATION ABOUT THE WORK OF GIDA:
Official Gida Website + Newsletter subscription (also our Contact Form in case you have any queries not covered here)
<http://www.tomasflamenco.wix.com/gida>

Gida Facebook Group:
<https://www.facebook.com/groups/Gidagida/>

My Story:

Karibu! (Swahili for hello).  Hi everyone, my name is Sophia Cole. I am a junior at the University of Colorado, Boulder studying International Affairs and French. In partnership with Dare Women's Foundation in Arusha, Tanzania, I am starting a project to make rugby accessible to Tanzanian girls. I first met the executive director of the Dare Women's Foundation, Maggie Duncan Simbeye, at the Conference on World Affairs in Boulder, CO, where I was her student-ambassador.  Since then, I have been working with Maggie to establish what is now the Dare Rugby Project.

My rugby career started by chance. I wandered into my university's team practice and asked to play. The moment I walked onto my first pitch, I fell in love with the sport. Rugby is an amazing game played by amazing people. Rugby is incredibly challenging and even more rewarding. This past year my hard work and dedication paid off when I had the amazing opportunity to train at the Olympic Training Center. I was also named a  2014 Pacific Mountain Rugby Conference all-star and a Junior All- American. In Spring 2015, I will be playing rugby in France while studying at l'Institut d’Études Politiques in Paris. In Summer 2015, I plan to travel to Tanzania to establish the first Dare Rugby team.

Why Rugby? 

Rugby is very popular in Tanzania, however, the opportunity for girls to play is rare. The goal of the Dare Rugby Project is to engage with the community and share rugby with girls who have the passion but no outlet. 

The need for this project is born from how critical a girl’s youth is to her future. Young women in Tanzania are faced with a great number of financial, physical, and psychological adversities.  In the face of these hardships, Dare Rugby will work to give young women the rugby experience so they can gain inspiration, self-discipline, and self -confidence through this amazing sport. The core values of rugby are teamwork, respect, enjoyment, discipline and sportsmanship. I hope that the game and its values will have a positive impact on the girls and the community of Arusha, Tanzania.

The Dare Woman’s Foundation is spreading news about conservation, education birth control, and nutritional education. The Dare Rugby Project is one of many components of The Dare Woman’s Foundation designed to improve the lives of the young women of Tanzania.

What We Need:

The Dare Rugby team is 22 girls strong. The first Dare Rugby team will play for two months in Summer 2015.

The monthly cost to the Dare Foundation is $20 per girl, the girls attend free of charge.  

In order of priority:

•$880 Cost for 22 girls to attend 

•$600 needed for food and clean drinking water

•$200 needed for rugby balls and jerseys

•$200 needed for transportation to and from practices and tournaments

• $1,400 for personal airfare to and from Tanzania

• + Fundraising costs

The total funds needed for the Dare Rugby Project is $3,400.

In the event we do not reach our $3,400 goal, Dare Rugby will still go on. We will put to use what is raised. Every donation helps!

    Thank You!!

    Contributing to our campaign is one of many ways you can help empower a young woman. For more information and updates on Dare Rugby please visit: http://www.darewomensfoundation.org

    Please use Indiegogo's share tools to share the Dare Rugby Project campaign and make some noise about our cause. 

    Thank you! Your contribution and support is greatly appreciated and will go a long way.

story:
What are we?

Roaring Brook Market is a sustainably-minded local foods grocery store and café in downtown Lancaster. In addition to stocking traditional grocery items, we will be featuring local and seasonal breakfast and lunch options in our cafe. 

Who are we?

Roaring Brook Market is the manifestation of a community-driven food movement. Sarah, Trex, Drew, and Rachel recognized the need for a local food outlet and came together through their shared passion for Lancaster city and belief in the revitalizing power of local food. The market will source goods primarily from within Lancaster and it’s neighboring counties, though our definition of local extends to an 100 miles radius the city. Customers can look forward to seeing grocery items, fresh produce, dry goods, and home and body care products on our shelves, as well as breakfast, lunch, coffee and to-go items in the café.  

Why Contribute?

In order to make this dream a reality, we need monetary support from the community to purchase the necessary equipment to make a grocery store and café operate. Not only is this campaign a way to bring another small business to Lancaster, but also a way for members of the community to become intrinsically involved in the success of the store. 

Where does the money go?

By donating to the campaign, supporters will help Roaring Brook purchase refrigeration equipment from which grocery items will be sold, ranging from produce to meat, to dairy and eggs. In addition to stressing local, we strive to be as sustainable as possible and have chosen energy-efficient models that match our mission.

We are also commited to offering our farmers, growers, and suppliers fair and equitable prices for their goods. In order to do this, we need to raise money for our start-up inventory. In addition to paying for equipment, a part of the money raised from the campaign will go towards making our suppliers' work financially viable. 

What we need:

Roaring Brook is on its way towards its full opening but is still short $15,000-$20,000 of the necessary funds for opening. The money raised from this campaign will go towards the purchase and installation of equipment. We are hoping to raise at least $15,000 to cover the cost of the following equipment:

  • 3-door LED Refrigeration Unit
  • 3-door LED Freezer Unit
  • Open Air LED Produce Case
  • Old Tyme Nut Grinder

What you get!

More importantly, what do you get from donating? Besides the supreme satisfaction of supporting a local business, we are offering reward packages for different levels of donation. We appreciate any and all that you can give, and look forward to seeing you in the store!

Out of towners, please include your shipping address so we can send you your reward!

Other ways you can help?

Spread the word! Tell your friends and share our campaign! Find us on Facebook, Twitter, and at www.roaringbrookmarket.com. Or just stop by the store and hang out with us. 

---------------------------------------UPDATE 7/8/13-------------------------------------------

Check out our Gallery to see an image of the t-shirts we're offering in thanks for your donations. The shirt is designed by Drew Nowacoski, local Lancaster artist and owner of Roaring Brook, and will be screenprinted by Zach Kolodziejski, a screenprinter also local to our beautiful city. If you purchase a perk of equal or greater value to Wear the Love, you can get your very own Roaring Brook shirt! 

 

---------------------------------------UPDATE 7/11/13-------------------------------------------

We've added a perk! Donate $200 (or more) and be an exclusive member of Roaring Brook Market Locavore Club. 10% off your purchases for a year as well as a free coffee everytime you walk in the door. 

 

---------------------------------------UPDATE 8/8/13-------------------------------------------

Three weeks into operations and we've learned several things--to support our downtown local food mission we need more cold storage, more fresh inventory, and more funding! Check out the coverage from the local news at:

http://lancasteronline.com/article/local/877321...

Other ways you can help?
Spread the word! Tell your friends and share our campaign! Find us on Facebook, Twitter, and at www.roaringbrookmarket.com. Or just stop by the store and hang out with us. 
---------------------------------------UPDATE 7/8/13-------------------------------------------
Check out our Gallery to see an image of the t-shirts we're offering in thanks for your donations. The shirt is designed by Drew Nowacoski, local Lancaster artist and owner of Roaring Brook, and will be screenprinted by Zach Kolodziejski, a screenprinter also local to our beautiful city. If you purchase a perk of equal or greater value to Wear the Love, you can get your very own Roaring Brook shirt! 
 
---------------------------------------UPDATE 7/11/13-------------------------------------------
We've added a perk! Donate $200 (or more) and be an exclusive member of Roaring Brook Market Locavore Club. 10% off your purchases for a year as well as a free coffee everytime you walk in the door. 
 
---------------------------------------UPDATE 8/8/13-------------------------------------------
Three weeks into operations and we've learned several things--to support our downtown local food mission we need more cold storage, more fresh inventory, and more funding! Check out the coverage from the local news at:
http://lancasteronline.com/article/local/877321...

story: Family Fund 2.0
